13     In tabulating the matrimonial assets available for distribution, I bore in mind the guidance given by the Family Division of the High Court in UYP v UYQ [2019] SGHCF 16, [2020] 3 SLR 683 at [4] that:

(a)     generally, the operative date for the identification of the matrimonial assets is the date of the Interim Judgment;

(b)     generally, matrimonial assets should be valued at the date of the ancillary matters hearing;

(c)     balances in bank accounts and Central Provident Fund (“CPF”) accounts are to be taken at the date of the Interim Judgment; and

(d)     where the parties have specifically agreed to use (as the value for an asset) a value as at a different date, the Court may adopt that value.

The parties’ cases

14     Under the Interim Judgment, the following ancillary matters were adjourned to be heard in Chambers:

(a)     division of matrimonial assets (including the Matrimonial Home);

(b)     the Wife’s claim for maintenance; and

(c)     costs of the divorce proceedings.

15     As regards the division of matrimonial assets, the parties agreed that the structured approach in ANJ v ANK [2015] SGCA 34, [2015] 4 SLR 1043 should apply. The parties also agreed that the parties’ direct financial contributions ratio should be 51.3 : 48.7 in the Husband’s favour. However, there was no agreement on the ratio of the parties’ indirect contributions. The Wife argues that the indirect contributions ratio should be 70 : 30 in the Wife’s favour. The Husband asks the Court to consider a 50 : 50 ratio for the parties’ indirect contributions.

16     The Wife also submitted that there should be a further uplift of at least 3% of the average ratio in her favour. After the Wife commenced the divorce on 5 May 2023, the Husband withdrew a sum of $5,000 on 1 June 2023, and a further sum of $25,000 on 3 June 2023, from his OCBC bank account. The Husband claimed, in DA4, that the withdrawals were made “completely for [the parties’] son”, to “help [the parties’] son defray his expenses towards his tuition fees and the initial payment of his BTO (Built to order) flat”.[note: 10] The Husband also exhibited certain documents in DA4 in support of this claim. The Wife submitted that those documents did not show that the combined sum of $30,000 was transferred to the parties’ son or used as payment for the son’s tuition fees or HDB flat, and that therefore an adverse inference should be drawn against the Husband, and there should be an uplift in the Wife’s favour of at least 3% of the average ratio of the Wife’s direct and indirect contributions.

17     As regards the Wife’s claim for maintenance, the Wife sought maintenance of $800 per month for 3 years. The Husband submitted that there should be no maintenance for the Wife. However, the Husband listed in DA1 and DA2, among his direct financial contributions towards the Matrimonial Home, a monthly payment of $300 described as “Loan repayment on behalf of Plaintiff”.[note: 11] The Husband also reiterated, at paragraph 26 of DA1, that he was “currently repaying” a “Loan of S$20,000.00 taken up by the Plaintiff”.

Division of the matrimonial assets

18     I deal first with the division of the matrimonial assets.

19     The Wife explained in considerable detail at paragraph 15 of PA1 why she was the main caregiver of the son, and why she should be regarded as having made the larger proportion of the indirect financial and non-financial contributions towards the matrimonial assets. The matters set out in paragraph 15 of PA1 that are relevant to the Wife’s indirect financial and non-financial contributions include the following:

(a)     In 1989, the Wife set up a printing business called APG using her savings. In order to take over the premises to be occupied by APG, the Wife paid the landlord around $20,000 of outstanding rent owed by the previous tenant. The Wife purchased machinery and equipment, including 4 cameras that cost more than $30,000 each. The Wife also paid for renovations costing around $15,000. The Wife estimated that she spent over $100,000 to set up APG.

(b)     The parties registered their marriage on 3 March 1992. The Wife paid for the parties’ first matrimonial property on her own, using her CPF moneys and cash. The Wife also paid for the renovations to, and furniture for, the matrimonial property. The Wife made all of those payments, as the Husband was then unemployed.

(c)     The Husband was assisting the Wife with the running of APG by the time the Wife became pregnant in 1995. However, the Wife still had to go to work during her pregnancy, because the Husband was not familiar with the running of APG.

(d)     The parties’ son was delivered by caesarean section, had jaundice after he was born, and had to be hospitalised for over 10 days. The Wife also had to return to the hospital after she was discharged, when the “wound split”. The Wife paid for the hospitalisation fees of over $20,000 using cash and her CPF moneys.

(e)     The Wife continued to cook and do household chores after giving birth to the parties’ son.

(f)     After the parties’ son was discharged from the hospital, the Wife brought the son out for “suntan” every morning. The Wife also brought the son for check-ups at the polyclinic for 18 months.

(g)     As the Husband was unfamiliar with aspects of APG’s business, the Wife would return to the office with the parties’ son to finish the work. While running APG’s business, the Wife topped up $30,000 into the Husband’s “Medishield account” (sic) for him.[note: 12]

(h)     In 1997, the Husband refused to let the Wife go back to running APG full-time, even though the Wife wanted to do so. The Wife therefore found a job, and engaged a domestic helper to look after the parties’ son while the Wife was at work. The Wife paid for the domestic helper’s salary and related expenses on her own, without help from the Husband. The Wife also took care of the parties’ son, and cooked dinner, after returning home from work.

(i)     In 1998, whenever the parties’ son fell sick while attending daycare, the Wife attended to the son.

(j)     In 1999, when the son was in kindergarten, the Wife would send the son to school and pick up the son from school.

(k)     The Husband left everything concerning the education of the parties’ son to the Wife. The Wife visited several schools before enrolling the son in a kindergarten that the Wife thought would provide a better environment for the son. The Wife also enrolled the son in an English course that cost around $1,600, which the Wife paid for using her salary.

(l)     When the parties’ son started primary school in 2003, the Wife would wake him up, get him ready for school, and wait with him for the school bus. The Wife also took leave to accompany the son on the first 3 days of school. When the son attended primary school in the afternoon, the Wife would go to work later, and pick up the son after work. The Wife cooked the family’s meals when she did not have to work on Sundays. The Wife helped the son with his homework until he was in Primary 4, when she could no longer help him. The Wife attended all the meet-the-parents sessions of the son’s school on her own.

(m)     Until 2007, the Wife continued to go back to APG after work to complete tasks that the Husband did not know how to do. When the parties’ son was young, the Wife would bring him along, and watch over him while she finished tasks. Throughout the years from 1989 to 2007, the Wife would liaise with APG’s clients, take orders, give quotations, and meet with APG’s clients after work, on Saturdays or while she was on leave.

(n)     The Wife paid for the family’s expenses without help from the Defendant, including car-related expenses for 5 cars purchased over 12 years and registered in the Husband’s name. The car-related expenses included monthly instalments, road tax, petrol, car park charges, insurance, ERP (or “Electronic Road Pricing”) charges and fines. The Wife paid for the expenses using her salary and the moneys in APG’s bank account.

(o)     The Wife gave the parties’ son pocket money (on top of what the Husband was giving) all the way until the son was in National Service. The Wife also paid for the son’s toys and other items while he was growing up.

(p)     When the Wife injured her spine in 2005, she had to pay for her surgery on her own. The Husband did not care for her after the surgery.

(q)     In 2007, when the Husband told the Wife that his friend wanted to join APG for $25,000, the Wife agreed and transferred the business to the Husband’s name. However, the Husband did not pay the Wife for the business, even though she followed up with him a few times; the Husband kept telling the Wife that the business was not making money and he could not pay her.

(r)     In 2009, when the parties’ son started attending secondary school, the Wife would send him to school. The Wife continued to send the son to school until he completed polytechnic education. She also sent him to his campsite, and sent him home when he booked out from camp, until he almost finished his National Service in 2019.

20     In contrast, paragraphs 18 and 19 of DA1 merely contained particulars of the Husband’s direct and indirect financial contributions. The indirect contributions particularised in paragraph 19 of DA1 comprised the son’s school expenses, pocket money, handphone charges, and expenses for weekend meals and healthcare. The bulk of those expenses were incurred after the Wife was retrenched in January 2010. The Husband repeated those particulars at paragraphs 18 and 19 of DA2. Although the Husband stated at paragraph 21 of DA2 that he had “devoted a lot of time and shared all caretaking responsibilities during the course of [the parties’] marriage”, the Husband provided no details of his indirect non-financial contributions. The Husband did not deny any of the Wife’s statements concerning her indirect financial and non-financial contributions. The Husband in fact acknowledged the Wife’s indirect non-financial contributions when he stated in paragraph 21 of DA2 that “both parties have expended huge efforts towards the upbringing of [the parties’] son during the course of [the parties’] marriage”.

21     The parties’ son made certain allegations concerning his upbringing in paragraph 6 of SA1. However, I disregarded those allegations, and similar allegations made by the Husband in paragraph 6 of DA4. To begin with, none of those allegations were relevant to the Wife’s applications for discovery and interrogatories, or to the Husband’s compliance with the orders made on 13 September 2024. Any allegations disputing the Wife’s indirect non-financial contributions should have been contained in DA2, and should have been made within the time allowed by the Court for the filing of DA2 (i.e. by 29 February 2024). Those allegations appeared to be an attempt to introduce belatedly, without the permission of the Court, evidence that is designed to prejudice the Court against the Wife, on an occasion where the Wife had no opportunity to respond to those allegations.

22     Having regard to the evidence contained in PA1, PA2, DA1 and DA2, it is clear that both parties have made indirect financial contributions over the course of the marriage. Given the course of time, and the lack of documentation, it will not be possible to say with certainty whether the Husband or the Wife made more indirect financial contributions. The Husband did not dispute the Wife’s contentions that she supported him and the family financially during the marriage. It appeared that the Husband stepped up after the Wife encountered difficulties with her health, employment and undertakings.

23     However, the Wife appeared to have made significantly more indirect non-financial contributions than the Husband over the course of the marriage. For instance, the Wife appeared to have been the son’s main caregiver until the Wife started to drive a taxi full-time in 2011. The bulk of the Wife’s indirect non-financial contributions were made in the early years of the parties’ marriage, during the formative years of the parties’ son. The details of the Wife’s indirect non-financial contributions, which were asserted in paragraph 15 of PA1 and summarised at paragraphs 15 and 16 of the Plaintiff’s written submissions, were not denied by the Husband in DA2. The Husband made vague statements, such as that he had “devoted a lot of time and shared all caretaking responsibilities” and “expended huge efforts towards the upbringing of [the parties’] son”, but provided no particulars of his indirect non-financial contributions, in DA1 and DA2.

24     All things considered, I assigned the parties’ indirect contributions the ratio of 60 : 40 in the Wife’s favour.

25     I agreed with the Wife’s submission that the Husband had failed to properly account for the total of $30,000 withdrawn from the Husband’s OCBC Account on 1 and 3 June 2023. The Husband did not explain how the documents exhibited at pages 5 to 13 of DA4 supported his claim that the withdrawals were made completely for the parties’ son, to help the son defray the son’s expenses. The exhibited documents did not suggest that the parties’ son was required to pay any amount of his tuition fees, or to repay any amount of his tuition fee loan, on or about 1 or 3 June 2023. Nor did the documents suggest that the son was required to pay any amount to the HDB for the son’s flat on or about 1 or 3 June 2023. The writ for divorce, statement of claim and statement of particulars were received by the Husband on 13 May 2023. The withdrawals were made just a few days before the Husband filed a Defence and Counterclaim on 7 June 2023, and appeared to be timed to reduce the amount of matrimonial assets available for distribution. Even if the son ultimately benefitted from the withdrawals made on 1 and 3 June 2023, that did not change the complexion of those withdrawals.

26     However, I did not think I should make an arbitrary uplift of 3% in the Wife’s favour on account of the Husband’s failure. If the Husband had properly accounted for that sum of $30,000, it would have formed part of the Husband’s direct financial contributions to the pool of matrimonial assets, and enlarged the pool of matrimonial assets available for distribution.

27     The parties arrived at the direct financial contributions ratio of 51.3 : 48.7 in the Husband’s favour on the basis that the Husband’s direct financial contributions amounted to $287,533.62 while the Wife’s direct financial contributions amounted to $272,785.35. If the sum of $30,000 was added back to the pool of matrimonial assets for the purpose of ascertaining the appropriate adjustment to the Wife’s share of the Joint Assets, then notionally the Husband’s direct financial contributions would increase to $317,533.62, or 53.8% of the parties’ total direct financial contributions of $590,318.97. The direct financial contribution ratio would then be 53.8 : 46.2 in the Husband’s favour.

28     As I have assigned the parties’ indirect contributions the ratio of 60 : 40 in the Wife’s favour, after averaging the parties’ direct and indirect contributions, I would arrive at a final ratio of 53.1 : 46.9 in the Wife’s favour.

29     If the sum of $30,000 was added back to the pool of matrimonial assets for the purpose of ascertaining the appropriate adjustment to the Wife’s share of the Joint Assets, then notionally the matrimonial assets available for distribution would be as follows:

30     If the Wife is awarded 53.1% of this notional total value of the matrimonial assets, the Wife’s share will amount to $345,650.35 (53.1% of $650,942.28). The Husband’s 46.9% share of this notional total value of the matrimonial assets, amounting to $305,291.93, would include the sums of $5,000 and $25,000 withdrawn by him on 1 and 3 June 2023, respectively.

31     If the parties are to retain the matrimonial assets in their respective names, leaving only the Joint Assets to be distributed, then:

(a)     the Wife’s share of the total value of the Joint Assets will be $263,729.47, after deducting the total value of the Wife’s Assets ($81,920.88) from the Wife’s share of the notional total value of the Matrimonial Assets ($345,650.35); and

(b)     the Husband’s share of the total value of the Joint Assets will be $156,979.63, after deducting the notional total value of the Husband’s Assets ($148,312.30, inclusive of the sums of $5,000 and $25,000 withdrawn by the Husband on 1 and 3 June 2023, respectively) from the Husband’s share of the notional total value of the Matrimonial Assets (46.9% of $650,942.28, or $305,291.93).

32     At $263,729.47, the Wife’s share of the total value of the Joint Assets is about 62.69% of the total value of the Joint Assets, amounting to $420,709.10. At $156,979.63, the Husband’s share of the total value of the Joint Assets is about 37.31% of the total value of the Joint Assets.

33     The Wife proposed that the Matrimonial Home be sold, and that the sale proceeds be applied as follows:

(a)     to make full payment of the outstanding housing loan to the HDB;

(b)     to pay the HDB resale levy (if any);

(c)     to pay all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the property;

(d)     to pay the Wife her share of of the value of the Matrimonial Home, from which the Wife will make the requisite refunds to her CPF accounts in accordance with the applicable CPF legislation; and

(e)     to pay the Husband his share of the value of the Matrimonial Home, from which the Husband will make the requisite refunds to his CPF accounts in accordance with the applicable CPF legislation.

34     The Husband proposed that the Matrimonial Home be transferred to the Husband, in consideration of the Husband paying the Wife her share of the value of the Matrimonial Home, after deducting the “outstanding mortgage to HDB”.

35     To give the Husband a first bite at the cherry, I made the following orders on the distribution of matrimonial assets:

(a)     The Wife is to transfer her share and interest in the Matrimonial Home to the Husband, upon the Husband paying the Wife:

(i)       62.69% of the value of the Matrimonial Home (as determined by a valuer that is mutually agreed to by the parties) after deducting the amount payable to the HDB on the outstanding housing loan; or

(ii)       $263,728.79, if the parties are unable to agree on a valuer, or the Wife does not agree to contribute to the costs of the valuation.

(b)     The Wife is to first utilise the payment to make the requisite refunds to her CPF accounts in accordance with the applicable CPF legislation.

(c)     The Husband is to bear all costs and disbursements relating to the transfer of the Wife’s share and interest in the Matrimonial Home to the Husband.

(d)     If the parties agree on a valuer, and the Wife agrees to contribute to the costs of the valuation, then the costs of the valuation are to be borne by the parties equally.

(e)     If the Husband is unable to pay the Wife the applicable amount set out in subparagraph (a)(i) or (ii), the Matrimonial Home is to be sold, and the sale proceeds are to be applied as follows:

(i)       to make full payment to the HDB of the outstanding housing loan;

(ii)       to pay the HDB resale levy (if any);

(iii)       to pay all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the property;

(iv)       to pay the Wife 62.69% of the sale proceeds (after deducting the sums mentioned in subparagraph (e)(i), (ii) and (iii)), from which the Wife will make the requisite refunds to her CPF accounts in accordance with the applicable CPF legislation; and

(v)       to pay the Husband 37.31% of the sale proceeds (after deducting the sums mentioned in subparagraphs (i), (ii) and (iii)), from which the Husband will make the requisite refunds to his CPF accounts in accordance with the applicable CPF legislation.

(f)     The Wife is to be paid $0.68 from the balance of $1.08 in the OCBC Savings Account held by the parties as a joint account.

(g)     The Husband is to be paid $0.40 from the balance of $1.08 in the OCBC Savings Account held by the parties as a joint account.

(h)     Each party is to retain all other assets in the sole name of that party.

36     To avoid doubt:

(a)     the amount of $263,728.79 mentioned in paragraph 35(a)(ii) was derived from 62.69% of the agreed net value of the Matrimonial Home as at 31 October 2023 (which is $420,708.02);

(b)     the amount of $0.68 mentioned in paragraph 35(f) represents the Wife’s 62.69% share of the balance of $1.08 in the OCBC Savings Account held by the parties as a joint account; and

(c)     the amount of $0.40 mentioned in paragraph 35(g) represents the Husband’s 37.31% share of the balance of $1.08 in the OCBC Savings Account held by the parties as a joint account.

37     In summary, upon the division of the matrimonial assets:

(a)     the Wife was awarded 53.1%, and the Husband was awarded 46.9%, of the notional total value of the matrimonial assets, if the sums of $5,000 and $25,000 withdrawn from the Husband’s OCBC Account on 1 and 3 June 2023, respectively, were added back;

(b)     the Wife would:

(i)       in relation to the Matrimonial Home:

(A)       receive 62.69% of the value of the Matrimonial Home (as determined by a valuer that is mutually agreed to by the parties) after deducting the amount payable to the HDB on the outstanding housing loan;

(B)       receive $263,728.79, which is 62.69% of the agreed net value of the Matrimonial Home as at 31 October 2023 ($420,708.02) calculated by deducting, from the estimated resale price of $455,000:

(I)       the outstanding balance on the housing loan of $30,868.33 as at 31 October 2023; and

(II)     the late payment charges of $3,423.65 as at 31 October 2023; or

(C)       receive 62.69% of the net sale proceeds of the Matrimonial Home, after deducting:

(I)       the amount payable to the HDB on the outstanding housing loan;

(II)     the HDB resale levy (if any); and

(III)    all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the Matrimonial Home;

(ii)       receive the amount of $0.68 from the balance of $1.08 in the OCBC Savings Account held by the parties as a joint account;

(iii)       retain the balance in the Wife’s UOB Savings Account (amounting to $258.64 as at 2 November 2023); and

(iv)       retain the Wife’s CPF moneys (amounting to $81,662.24 as at 1 November 2023); and

(c)     the Husband would:

(i)       in relation to the Matrimonial Home:

(A)       retain the Matrimonial Home, upon paying the Wife the applicable amount that the Wife was to receive; or

(B)       receive 37.31% of the net sale proceeds of the Matrimonial Home, after deducting:

(I)       the amount payable to the HDB on the outstanding housing loan;

(II)     the HDB resale levy (if any); and

(III)    all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the Matrimonial Home;

(ii)       receive the amount of $0.40 from the balance of $1.08 in the OCBC Savings Account held by the parties as a joint account;

(iii)       retain the balance in the Husband’s OCBC Account (amounting to $9,376.22 as at 7 December 2023);

(iv)       retain the Husband’s CPF moneys (amounting to $108,936.08 as at 25 October 2023); and

(v)       not be required to account for the sums of $5,000 and $25,000 withdrawn from the Husband’s OCBC Account on 1 and 3 June 2023, respectively.

Maintenance for the Wife

38     I deal next with the Wife’s claim for maintenance of $800 a month for 3 years. The Husband submitted that there should be no maintenance for the Wife.

39     When I decided the matter in January 2025, the Husband was 67 years old while the Wife was 63 years old.

40     According to PA1, the Wife’s last job was as a coffee shop assistant with a monthly take-home income of $1,267 per month.[note: 13] By the time the Wife affirmed PA1 on 8 December 2023, she had stopped working due to poor health.[note: 14] The Wife claimed that her monthly expenses amounted to $1,203.[note: 15]

41     The Husband conceded that the Wife was “currently not working due to health reasons”.[note: 16] However, he contended that the “burden” of maintaining the Wife could not be imposed by him, as:

(a)     “both parties have had to lead a very frugal conservative lifestyle in the last few years of [their] marriage”;[note: 17]

(b)     the amount that he proposed to pay the Wife to buy over her share of the Matrimonial Home would be sufficient to tide over her expenses;[note: 18]

(c)     his take home salary was “barely enough to sustain [his] personal expenses of S$1020.00 (average per month) and [his] contributions towards the matrimonial flat S$1442.50”;[note: 19] and

(d)     he was “already facing a shortfall of about S$575.50 every month”, was “also going through extreme stress and financial hardship currently”, and was “struggling to manage finances [himself] at [his] old age”.[note: 20]

42     According to DA2, the Husband’s monthly take-home income (or net salary) was $1,887 per month.[note: 21] The Husband also received Workfare Income Supplement Scheme payments (including cash payments of $140 per month from April to September 2023, $135 per month from October to December 2023, $109 in January 2024, $100 in February 2024, and $135 in April 2024),[note: 22] some occasional cash payments from the Government (such as Silver Support payouts),[note: 23] and some bonuses from his employer.[note: 24]

43     The Husband claimed that his monthly personal expenses, and his monthly direct financial contributions towards the acquisition or improvement of the Matrimonial Home during the course of the marriage, were $1,020 and $1,442.50, respectively.[note: 25] The Husband’s claim in paragraph 16 of DA2 that his personal expenses included a monthly allowance of $200 for his mother appeared questionable, as that allowance was not mentioned in the Husband’s list of personal expenses set out at paragraph 16 of DA1, even though that allowance was a significant expense that exceeded 10 percent of what the Husband declared to be his net monthly salary. However, there were other expenses listed by the Husband that appeared reasonable. For instance, the Husband claimed, when DA2 was affirmed on 11 March 2024, that he was paying the following monthly expenses (which collectively would expend most of the Husband’s monthly take home salary): (a) $837 for the housing loan for the Matrimonial Home; (b) $67.50 for service and conservancy charges; (c) $40 for water; (d) $100 for electricity; (e) $13 for property tax; (f) $100 for transportation; (g) $450 for food and beverages; and (h) $300 for “Loan repayment on behalf of Plaintiff”.[note: 26]

44     It was not disputed that the Wife had borrowed at least $18,000 under a loan for which the Husband had acted as a guarantor, and that the Husband had made monthly repayments of $300 towards the loan, at least until 28 April 2023,[note: 27] before the Wife filed the writ for divorce. The Wife estimated the balance due under the loan to be $7,200.[note: 28] If the Husband continued to make monthly repayments of $300 towards the loan, the Husband would have to make at least 24 payments of $300 before the loan is repaid.

45     If (as the Husband claimed at paragraphs 18 and 22 of DA2) the Husband had been paying $300 per month towards the loan taken out by the Wife, then the Husband was in fact already supporting the Wife financially by discharging her liability under the loan, and had budgeted for such financial support.

46     Section 114(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961, insofar as it is material, states:

114.—(1)    In determining the amount of any maintenance to be paid by a man to his wife or former wife, ... the court must have regard to all the circumstances of the case, including the following matters:

(a)    the income, earning capacity, property and other financial resources which each of the parties to the marriage has or is likely to have in the foreseeable future;

(b)    the financial needs, obligations and responsibilities which each of the parties to the marriage has or is likely to have in the foreseeable future;

(c)    ...

(d)    the age of each party to the marriage and the duration of the marriage;

(e)    any physical or mental disability of either of the parties to the marriage;

(f)    the contributions made by each of the parties to the marriage to the welfare of the family, including any contribution made by looking after the home or caring for the family; and

(g)    ...

47     The Husband did not dispute the Wife’s evidence that she had supported him and the family during the parties’ marriage. However, the Husband declined to reciprocate when the Wife was in poor health and unable to work, primarily on the ground that he lacked the means to support her. While the amount to be paid by the Husband to the Wife for her share of the Matrimonial Home may go some way to meeting her expenses, a part of that amount would have to be refunded to her CPF accounts in accordance with the applicable CPF legislation, and another part of that amount would be required by her for alternative accommodation. I was mindful that both parties had limited financial resources. As the Husband claimed that his monthly expenses included a repayment of $300 a month towards the discharge of the loan taken by the Wife (for which the Husband was a guarantor), there would be no increase in the Husband’s monthly expenses if he was ordered to continue the monthly repayments, for a period of 2 years, in satisfaction of the Wife’s claim for maintenance.

48     Having regard to all the circumstances of the case, and in particular the matters listed in section 114(1)(a), (b), (d), (e) and (f) of the Women’s Charter 1961, I ordered the Defendant to repay $300 a month for a period of 2 years towards the discharge of the loan taken out by the Wife, in satisfaction of the Wife’s claim for maintenance.

Costs

49     At the hearing on 21 January 2025, the Wife’s counsel applied for the Husband to pay costs of $1,500 to $2,000, as the Court had agreed with the Wife’s submissions for indirect contributions and her claim for maintenance. The Wife’s counsel also sought costs for the original hearing of the ancillary matters on 18 December 2024, which had to be adjourned when the Husband’s counsel failed to attend the hearing. By a letter dated 18 December 2024 sent after the hearing, the Husband’s counsel apologised for his absence, and explained that due to an oversight following the departure of a paralegal, the Husband’s counsel was scheduled with 3 other matters (including a mediation at the State Courts) that clashed with the hearing.

50     The Husband’s counsel left the issue of costs to the Court. He pointed out that this was a “small family matter”, and asked for the costs of the adjournment to be awarded against him (instead of his client) as the adjournment was caused by his error.

51     I am mindful that in JBB v JBA [2015] SGHCF 6, [2015] 5 SLR 153, at [32] and [33], the Family Division of the High Court observed that there are usually good reasons in the context of matrimonial proceedings to depart from the guiding principle that costs should follow the event. Citing rule 852(2) of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (as in force at the time that JBB v JBA was decided), the Court also observed that the principle that costs should follow the event may be departed from where it is appropriate to do so. In the context of divorce proceedings, the Court gave as examples (of when this would be appropriate) cases where the judgment of divorce was obtained based on a “neutral” fact such as “living apart” or upon compromise by the parties to proceed on an uncontested basis (whatever the fact relied on), or where an order of costs would aggravate the acrimony between the parties and it was important in the circumstances to reduce the risk of increasing hostility. The Court also observed that in the context of the hearing of ancillary matters (which may be considered to be discrete from the divorce proceedings), it is the conduct of the parties in the proceedings which will have greater relevance in the exercise of the discretion in determining costs, and that a party who has been uncooperative in disclosing his or her assets and means would be unlikely to receive a favourable costs order.

52     Under rule 852(2) of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (as in force immediately before 15 October 2024),[note: 29] if the Court in its discretion sees fit to make any order as to the costs of or incidental to any proceedings, the Court shall order the costs to follow the event, except when it appears to the Court that in the circumstances of the case some other order should be made. The hearing of the ancillary matters before me was not one to which any of the usual reasons (for departing from the principle that costs should follow the event) applied. As the Wife had substantially succeeded in obtaining the share of the Joint Assets that she was seeking, and as the Husband was also ordered to repay $300 a month for a period of 2 years towards the discharge of the loan taken out by the Wife in satisfaction of Wife’s claim for maintenance, the Wife was the successful party at the hearing of the ancillary matters, and should therefore in principle be awarded the costs of that hearing.

53     For the hearing of the ancillary matters, the Wife and the Husband filed 2 affidavits each. These were:

(a)     PA1 (16 pages of statements and 126 pages of exhibits);

(b)     PA2 (5 pages of statements and 6 pages of exhibits);

(c)     DA1 (7 pages of statements and 174 pages of exhibits); and

(d)     DA2 (8 pages of statements and 87 pages of exhibits).

54     The main hearing of the ancillary matters on 14 January 2025 lasted from 2:30 pm to 3:13 pm. The short hearing was made possible by the prior filing of a 14-page written submission on behalf of the Wife (the page count excludes the cover page, the table of contents and the Annex to the written submissions) and a 13-page written submission on behalf of the Husband (the page count excludes the cover page). This was followed by a hearing on 21 January 2025 lasting from 8:30 am to 9:35 am, at which I delivered an oral judgment and received submissions on the form that the order for maintenance should take and on costs.

55     All things considered, I ordered the Husband to pay the Wife the costs of the ancillary matters fixed at $1,500 all in. I also ordered the Husband’s counsel to personally bear the costs of adjournment on 18 December 2024, fixed at $100.

[note: 1]See PA1 Section A paragraph 2.

[note: 2]See DA1 paragraphs 2 and 6(b), and DA2 paragraphs 2 and 6(b).

[note: 3]See PA1 Section A paragraph 3 and Annex A, DA1 paragraph 3, and DA2 paragraph 3.

[note: 4]See PA1 Section A paragraphs 3 and 4 and Annexes A and D.

[note: 5]See PA1 Section A paragraph 3, Section B paragraph 8 and Annex C, DA1 paragraph 12, and DA2 paragraph 12.

[note: 6]See PA1 Section A paragraph 3, Section B paragraph 8 and Annex B.

[note: 7]See PA1 Section B paragraph 9 and Annex F.

[note: 8]See DA1 paragraph 12. According to DA2 paragraph 12, the balance was $6,317.74 as at 25 October 2023. However, the bank statements exhibited at pages 14 to 19 of DA2 show the ledger balance and available balance for the Husband’s OCBC account to be $9,375.14 when those bank statements were printed. As the balance declared in DA2 paragraph 12 was not consistent with the value for that balance reflected in the exhibited bank statements, I preferred the balance of $9,376.22 as at 7 December 2023 declared in DA1 paragraph 12. Further, the Husband’s counsel adopted the figure of $9,375.14 in his calculation of the Husband’s direct contributions towards the pool of matrimonial assets, in paragraph 18 of the Husband’s written submissions filed on 13 January 2025.

[note: 9]See DA1 paragraph 13. According to DA2 paragraph 13, the balance was $114,174.17 as at 27 February 2024. As balances in CPF accounts are generally to be taken at the date of the Interim Judgment, and DA1 paragraph 13 set out the balance on a date closer to the date of the interim judgment, the balance in DA1 paragraph 13 is to be preferred to the balance in DA2 paragraph 13. Further, the Husband’s counsel adopted the figure of $108,936.08 in his calculation of the Husband’s direct contributions towards the pool of matrimonial assets, in paragraph 18 of the Husband’s written submissions filed on 13 January 2025.

[note: 11]See DA1 paragraph 18 and DA2 paragraph 18.

[note: 12]The reference to the Husband’s “Medishield account” is probably a reference to the Husband’s medisave account, or the Husband’s policy or premium under the MediShield Scheme, the MediShield Life Scheme or the MediShield component of an integrated health insurance plan. The Husband did not dispute, or seek to clarify, the Wife’s claim that she had topped up $30,000 into the Husband’s “Medishield account”.

[note: 13]See PA1 Section B paragraphs 2 and 3.

[note: 14]See PA1 Section A paragraph 2, and Section B paragraphs 3, 15 (5th subparagraph at page 14) and 18.

html:
XNO v XNP

XNO v XNP
[2025] SGFC 63

Case Number:SS 1477 of 2024
Decision Date:15 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Mother in person and unrepresented; The Father in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XNO — XNP

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

15 May 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       SS 1477/2024 (“SS 1477”) was the Mother’s application for a personal protection order (“PPO”) on behalf of her son, against the Father.

2       I heard the trial over two tranches between December 2024 and February 2025. Both the Mother and the Father were unrepresented at the hearing before me. The Mother had one witness at the hearing: her current Husband (“X”).

3       I reserved judgment after hearing oral submissions from both parties. On 2 April 2025, I delivered judgment, dismissing the Mother’s application. These are my grounds of decision.

4       The law makes it clear that to succeed in an application for a PPO, the applicant must establish two things.

5       First, that the respondent had committed an act of family violence (as is defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961)[note: 1] or that the respondent was likely to commit family violence. What this means is that the applicant does not actually have to show that the respondent had committed family violence – rather, it is sufficient to show that the respondent was likely to do so: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [16].

6       Second, the applicant must show that the PPO is “necessary for the protection” of the family member that is sought to be protected. This is, in essence, a risk assessment: XJB v XJC [2025] SGFC 21 at [70] citing XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [19]. The court will consider factors such as the likelihood of interactions between the parties, whether the underlying cause for family violence remains unresolved, and respondent specific factors (eg where the respondent has displayed a propensity for violence).

7       The applicant must establish both these aforementioned elements on a balance of probabilities. As to what the “balance of probabilities” means, a useful definition may be found in Lua Bee Kiang (administrator of the estate of Chew Kong Seng, deceased) v Yeo Chee Siong [2019] 1 SLR 145 where the Court of Appeal observed:

65    Proof on a balance of probabilities is a standard of proof that is applied in civil cases generally to discern whether a past event happened. Such proof is necessary for the court to determine “whether [the plaintiff’s] case is more probably true than untrue” (see Jeffrey Pinsler, Evidence and the Litigation Process (LexisNexis, 6th Ed, 2017) at para 12.092). In the absence of an exhaustive historical record, the notion that an event was more likely than not to have happened is an epistemic proxy for whether it did in fact happen…

[emphasis added]

8       It is with these principles in mind that I turn now to consider the Mother’s application in SS 1477.

Alleged incidents of family violence

The incident on 29 July 2024

9       The latest incident of family violence which the Mother complained of took place on the 29th of July 2024. This was the Mother’s account of events as set out in her complaint form.

10     According to the Mother, when she was arriving at her parent’s residence, she saw the Father grabbing the son forcefully by his shoulder. At this time, the Mother’s niece was next to the Father.

11     The Mother was shocked to see the Father. Although there was a court order granting care and control of the son to her, the order also provided for the Father to have access. However, the Father had to give two weeks advance notice. The Mother says that the Father never gave such notice and would simply turn up unannounced.

12     The Mother confronted the Father as to where he was taking the son. The Father ignored her and simply asked why she cared before heading off with both the son, and the Mother’s niece, to the carpark.

13     Not wanting to confront the Father (because she was pregnant at the time and thus feared for her safety), the Mother went up to her parent’s home to ask why the Father had taken the son. Her parents told her that they were unaware of this.

14     Afraid that the Father would take the son away to Malaysia, given that he had mentioned doing so previously, the Mother called X for help. X sought police assistance and made his way down.

15     When the Mother went down to the foot of the block, she saw the Father “provoking and instigating” her Husband to a fight with “vulgar actions and verbal abuse”. The Mother called out to the son and her niece to come with her. The Father, and his girlfriend, pulled the son away.

16     The Father kept mocking and taunting the Mother’s family members. The Mother claimed that the Father had grabbed the son by the neck, which caused the son “fear and hurt”. The son was traumatised and “started crying all the way”.

17     The Mother pleaded with the Father to let the son go. The Father refused. He continued to hurl insults and instigated X to fight him. The Mother alleges that the Father was “behaving like a wild insane person as he has always done before”.

18     X began to record the incident. This deescalated the situation somewhat, although the Father continued to “grab on” to the son’s neck.

19     When asked to let go of the son, the Father pulled the son “even tighter” and told the Mother to keep her hands off the son otherwise he would hit her. The Mother says that this caused “fear in [the] son, [her] niece and other family members” as she was “26 weeks pregnant” and “all feared that [the Father] would harm [her] and [the] baby”.

20     The situation was defused when the police arrived on the scene. The Mother says the officers advised her to apply for a PPO after hearing why they had called for police assistance.

21     I do not find that the Father had committed an act of family violence on the son in this incident.

22     The Mother had produced a set of images and videos which were taken by X. The images and videos show a tiny snippet of what had taken place during that incident. It was clear that the son had, unfortunately, been caught up in the heated argument between the Father, and the Mother and her relatives (including X). Both sides were shouting at each other, and any verbal abuse which the Father had hurled, was certainly not directed at the son.[note: 2]

23     As to the Mother’s specific allegation that the Father had held the son by his neck during this incident, I do not find this to be the case.

24     For one, the Mother had considerable difficulty describing exactly how the Father had allegedly grabbed the son by the neck. Initially, the Mother said:[note: 3]

Yes. And my son’s face was frozen up because when I called---when I called him then he was actually holding my son over the neck, like over the shoulder like that. So, I’m not so sure what was that. So, when I went back home then my ha---uh, I called my husband immediately, then my sister also realised that, uh, it was not a access date or---so, she went down to bring my son back, lah. And I also went down together to see---to bring my son back. Then what I noticed is I saw---uh, my hus---when my husband arrived, I saw my husband below also, ah. So, I saw [the Father] is like, you know, scolding my husband in vulgarities. He was holding my son’s neck like that, grabbing my son neck when I saw him also, ah. So, I---he was---and scolding my husband vulgarities and taunting him to fight in front of the child, lah. Then I---immediately I went in front of him and---and told him, “Please leave him alone. Let him go. Let him go. That I’m here already, I’m the mother, I’m here already. You let him go.” But he insists not to let go, and he asked me to move away before he hit me. I’m actually pregnant that time, ah. I was 7, 8 months pregnant, lah. So, he was saying that he will hit me if I come nearer or touch my son. So, my husband was a bit---my husband was very, uh, upset with this, ah. Then my mum also came down because it was a big commotion down---it was so loud, the neighbour also was there. And he was dragging [the son] by the neck, pulling him here and there, not letting him go. So, I was like wondering why he’s doing this? But when I want to approach him, he keep on saying that he will hit me and hit me, ah. Then, uh, he keep on, like, you know, mocking, threatening, you know, all this, what he used to do he was doing it on that day, ah. He---he stopped when the police arrived. Until then he was just dragging my son here and there. So, this was---happened on that day, huh, then, uh--- yah, then my husband took a video and some shots like, uh, some shots that he’s been---he threatening my son and scolding my son, and---and he also like, uh, telling me that he will hit me, repeating again and again, approaching me. The girlfriend was actually stopping him, ah. In the video, you can see, yah. Then, uh, when I went back home, I had a conversation with my son. So, my son was actually very traumatised by the incident. I’m calmed him down and you know, we had a talk over this incident. He was saying that he was very upset. I asked him why---like when I was---I saw you below under the lift why didn’t you just come? Then he said that he was grabbing him very hard here, not letting him go. Then he---he also very worried that he might harm me. So, because I’m also pregnant. So, he---he’s very scared he will harm me so, he just followed him. Then when, uh---then he said that---uh, he was very upset that he was not letting him go when he was---he was grabbing during the incident when he saw my husband, right, so, he was in pain also, ah. So, the next day he didn’t go to school because he was very traumatised that he will appear again and create this, uh---this, uh, this unpleasant scene again, ah. So, he was very scared to open the door also then, uh, I let him rest. He was---he was very, um, threatened and he was full of fear.

[emphasis added]

25     However, it soon became apparent that there were gaps in the Mother’s memory when she was asked to describe, in detail, how the Father had grabbed the son by the neck.[note: 4]

26     Even if one accounts for the erosion of memory with the passage of time, one cannot ignore the context in which the Father had allegedly grabbed the son by the neck. It was clear that this had taken place amidst a heated quarrel between the Father, the Mother and her relatives. The videos and the images that had been produced showed that there was a tussle over the son, and the Father was trying to hold on to him by his left shoulder.

27     Considering the above-mentioned points together, I found it highly unlikely that the Father had grabbed the son by the neck, in a manner that would have caused the son hurt, as the Mother had alleged. In my judgment, this incident on 29 July 2024 was a dispute over whether the Father was entitled to see the son pursuant to the access order. Simmering tempers had boiled over and erupted into a full-blown argument, with both sides shouting at each other and tussling over the son.

The incident on 11 February 2024

28     In this incident, the Mother alleges that the Father had made a phone call to her parent’s house, knowing that the son was there. The Father had scolded the son and asked why he did not want to stay overnight with him.

29     The son had told the Father that he was afraid of being beaten by him if he stayed overnight. The Mother intervened when she saw the son crying and shivering in fear. She told the Father that the son did not want to stay overnight.

30     The Father was incensed. He began to hurl vulgarities at the Mother over the phone. The Mother hung up. At this point, the son had gone to close the house door, fearing that the Father would turn up to cause trouble.

31     The Mother says that the Father had, through his actions, placed the son in fear of hurt. She also alleges that his actions constitute continual harassment.

32     The Father’s account is markedly different. He says that the son was not speaking properly to him when he called. He asked the son to ask the Mother why he could not come and see him on his birthday. The son kept quiet for a while, and then began to cry.

33     That was when the Mother picked up the phone. The first thing she asked was: “why did you make my son cry?”. The Father was puzzled. He said he did not know. He also confronted the Mother for interrupting the conversation he was having with the son. The both of them started arguing.[note: 5]

34     I do not find that the Mother had proven, on a balance of probabilities, that the Father had committed family violence in this incident.

35     The Mother’s evidence of what the Father had said to the son, and the manner in which he had spoken to the son was based on what she claims the son had told her. The Mother testified that she had asked the son what the Father had said to him, and the son had shared that the Father was forcing him to stay with him overnight, and was scolding him harshly.

36     The basic point is that the Mother did not actually hear what the Father had said to the son. She had only seen the son crying, before she stepped in to intervene. She did not actually hear what the Father had said to the son, nor did she hear how the Father had spoken to the son.

37     Even if I were inclined to accept the Mother’s account, that this was how the Father had spoken to the son and that he had tried to force the son to stay overnight with him, this would not, in my judgment, constitute family violence as defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961. One might say that the Father should have, and could have, handled his disappointment at his son’s refusal to stay overnight with him a little better. But the mere act of scolding the son for refusing to stay overnight, and trying to force him to do so, does not, in my judgment, fall within the definition of family violence.

The incident on 24 October 2023

38     The next incident complained of happened on 24 October 2023 – this happened a day before the son’s birthday. The Mother claims that the Father had called the son and shouted at him. The Mother also claims that the Father had told the son that he was going to kill her.

39     I do not find that the Mother had proven, on a balance of probabilities, that the Father had actually told the son that he was going to kill her, or that the Father had indeed shouted at the son. Again, the Mother did not actually hear what the Father had said to the son.[note: 6]

The incident on 6 November 2023

40     I deal next, with the incident on 6 November 2023. The Mother’s complaint is that the Father had gotten angry when she rejected his requests for access to the son.[note: 7] She says that she had rejected his request for access because the son was uncomfortable being with him.

41     The Father had not committed any family violence on the son in this incident. The crux of the Mother’s complaint was that the Father had gotten very angry when his request for access was denied. There is nothing, even on the face of the Mother’s complaint, to suggest that the Father had done anything to the son on the 6th of November 2023. In any event, it is evident, from both the Father’s and the Mother’s account, that the Father did not speak to the son on that day.

Whether the Father was likely to commit family violence on the son

42     Having dealt with the specific incidents complained of, I move now to consider whether it is likely that the Father would commit family violence on the son.

43     I do not find that the Father is likely to do so.

44     While the Mother had sought to characterise the Father as a violent individual, the evidence put before me had not gone so far as to establish that any propensity for violence that the Father may have had would make it likely that he would commit family violence on the son.

45     Further, while it was alleged that the Father was physically abusive towards the son (for example, the Mother alleged that the Father would hit the son with a belt), there was no evidence put before me to corroborate this (ie, medical reports showing that the son had been physically abused).

46     Finally, both the Mother and X had given evidence about the Father’s drinking habits. Specifically, the Mother had given evidence that the Father would get drunk, and when he did, he would lose all sense and control and become violent. Even accepting that the Father does have a drinking problem, and would turn violent when he becomes drunk, there was no evidence before me to suggest that this posed a demonstrable risk to the son.

47     On the contrary, the video which the Father had put in evidence, in my judgment spoke to the affection he had for his son. While I am conscious of the possibility that the son may have been encouraged to act as though he was happy in front of the camera, I do not find that to be the case. The son’s demeanour in the video does show that both the Father and the son were genuinely happy in each other’s company.

Whether it was necessary to order a PPO

48     In considering the necessity of ordering a PPO, it is well established that the court essentially undertakes a risk assessment as to the likelihood of the respondent committing family violence on the person sought to be protected.

49     In the present case, I did not consider it necessary to order a PPO. For one, the present arrangement was that the son would live with the Mother and her family, and the Father would have access. The Father is allotted a period of time every week to see the son. If there were any signs of family violence on his part, that would be easily picked up when the son is returned to the Mother upon the end of the Father’s access.

50     Further, I do not find any hint of animosity or ill will directed by the Father towards the son. As I have mentioned, it was apparent to me from the video the Father had produced, that he does, indeed, love his son. One other piece of evidence pointing to this conclusion was the Father’s recollection of happy moments he had spent with his son.

Conclusion

51     I thus dismissed the Mother’s application in SS 1477. I would add that if one takes a step back and considers the evidence in totality, the real dispute at hand was over access arrangements to the son. It was clear to me that there was considerable frustration on both the Father’s and Mother’s part as to the practical aspects of the access arrangements as reflected in the court order. That had led to repeated arguments between them. The son had, unfortunately, been caught in the middle, and that thus gave rise to the basis for the Mother’s complaint.

52     I will conclude with some brief remarks to the Mother and the Father:

(a)     You are both an important part of your son’s life. While you may have chosen to each go your own separate ways after the divorce, your son is inextricably bound to the both of you by ties of kinship. That means you have but one choice: you must work together to give your son the best possible start in life.

(b)     The law makes it abundantly clear that parenting is a joint obligation. I would strongly encourage the both of you to take this opportunity to start on a clean slate – set aside your differences, and see how you can both work together for the sake of your son.

[note: 1]References to provisions of the Women’s Charter 1961 are references to the provisions in force prior to the 2nd of January 2025.
