html:
XMS v XMR and other matters

XMS v XMR and other matters
[2025] SGFC 56

Case Number:SS 1306, 1308 and 1462 of 2024
Decision Date:27 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Husband in person and unrepresented; Abdul Rahman Bin Mohd Hanipah (Abdul Rahman Law Corporation) and Patrick Fernandez (Fernandez LLC) for the Wife.
Parties: XMS — XMR

Equity – Defences – Acquiescence

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

27 May 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       The parties to these applications are Husband and Wife. They have three young children aged 14, 12 and 5. These were their respective applications that came before me:

(a)     SS 1306/2024 (“SS 1306”). This was the Wife’s application. She sought a PPO for herself. The Husband is the respondent.

(b)     SS 1462/2024 (“SS 1462”). This was the Wife’s application. She sought a PPO for the three children. The Husband is the respondent.

(c)     SS 1308/2024 (“SS 1308”). This was the Husband’s application. He sought a PPO for himself as well as the three children. The Wife is the respondent. In addition, the Husband also seeks a domestic exclusion order (“DEO”), to exclude the Wife from the matrimonial property.

2       I heard the trial of all three matters. The Husband was self-represented. The Wife was initially represented by Mr Abdul Rahman, and subsequently, by Mr Patrick Fernandez (“Mr Fernandez”) who took over conduct of the matter.

3       After the trial, I reserved judgment and directed parties to file written submissions. I delivered judgment on 29 April 2025. These are the reasons for my decision.

The law

4       These are the applicable legal principles relating to family violence.

5       To succeed in an application for a PPO, the applicant must prove, on a balance of probabilities, two things (see XEN v XEO [2024] SGFC 94 at [5] – [9]). First, that the respondent had committed an act of family violence (as is defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961)[note: 1] or that the respondent was likely to commit family violence. Second, that it was necessary for the court to order the PPO. In assessing the necessity of ordering a PPO, the court essentially undertakes a risk assessment.

6       There was, however, one other point which I had to consider. Both the Husband’s application in SS 1308, and the Mother’s application in SS 1306 were also premised on incidents that took place a decade ago. In light of this, I called for written submissions on whether acquiescence could be invoked in the context of an application under Part 7 of the Women’s Charter 1961.

7       Mr Fernandez argued, in relation to the Wife’s application, that acquiescence does not apply to a PPO application based on continual harassment. That is because, to establish continual harassment, the applicant must show that the acts complained of are sufficiently repetitive in nature. Application of acquiescence would therefore “prejudice every PPO application based on continual harassment”.[note: 2] In this connection, Mr Fernandez argued that applying the law on acquiescence would also limit the court’s ability to determine whether “family violence is likely to be committed”.[note: 3]

8       Mr Fernandez, however, argued that acquiescence should apply to the Husband’s application, given his allegations that the Wife had caused him hurt, or placed him in fear of hurt. In this connection, Mr Fernandez argues that the Husband’s inaction to “file a PPO application for an incident that occurred between 2023 and 2025 constituted a waiver or an abandonment of rights”.[note: 4]

9       I take, as my starting point, the concept of acquiescence as has been sketched out in our local jurisprudence. This was a point recently canvassed by the Appellate Division of the High Court in Salaya Kalairani v Appangam Govindhasamy [2023] SGHC(A) 40, and a useful summary may be found in that judgment at [49] – [56].

10     In particular, the court noted (at [55]) that cases such as Tan Yong San v Neo Kok Eng [2011] SGHC 30, Genelabs Diagnostics Pte Ltd v Institut Pasteur [2000] 3 SLR(R) 530, and Ho Yew Kong v Sakae Holdings Ltd and other appeals and other matters [2018] 2 SLR 333 appeared to illustrate that acquiescence could be used as a defence against statutory claims.

11     The court also noted (at [56]) that:

56    In this context we note that the term acquiescence has been used in varying contexts by many courts and for that reason has been described as possessing “a chameleon-like quality” (see Orr v Ford [1989] 84 ALR 146 at 157) or a “mongrel concept that is drawn from other doctrines, but does not have a distinct breed of its own” (see Lusina Ho, “The Importance of Being Earnest: The Doctrines of Laches and Acquiescence” in Defences in Equity (Paul S Davies, Simon Douglas and James Goudkamp eds (Oxford: Hart Publishing, 2018) at p 326). For the purposes of these grounds of decision, we define acquiescence as the Court of Appeal defined it in Sakae Holdings, as circumstances founding an estoppel, a waiver or an abandonment of rights. In Sakae Holdings, the Court of Appeal held at [188] that “[t]he essence of acquiescence is that a plaintiff who knows about the conduct which it complains of and yet does nothing to object to or prevent such conduct may be taken to have made a representation to the defendant that it does not object to that conduct, which representation may found an estoppel, a waiver or an abandonment of rights” [emphasis added]. Therefore, in considering whether acquiescence was made out on the facts, we considered the key question to be whether the plaintiffs had made a representation which may found an estoppel, a waiver or an abandonment of rights.

[emphasis added]

12     Adopting the definition of acquiescence as set out by the Court of Appeal (“CA”) in Sakae Holdings and affirmed by the Appellate Division of the High Court in Salaya, it appears, at first blush, that acquiescence could be invoked in the context of applications for PPOs. Simply put: if an applicant is aware of incidents of family violence, but takes no steps to file an application for a PPO until several years have passed, this conduct could be taken as representing that the applicant has no objection to such conduct, and this representation may found either an estoppel, a waiver or abandonment of rights (to borrow the words used by the CA in Sakae Holdings). For example, such a representation could amount to a waiver in that the applicant had “voluntary[ily] or intentional[ly] relinquish[ed] a known right,[note: 5] claim or privilege”: Salaya at [58] citing Audi Construction Pte Ltd v Kian Hiap Construction Pte Ltd [2018] 1 SLR 317 at [54].

13     However, that a representation had been made by the applicant in choosing not to file an application for a PPO is only half of the equation. As was noted in Salaya at [65], there must also be reliance by the defendant. In the familial context of PPO applications, one might argue that such reliance could manifest in the form of the defendant taking active steps to correct their behaviour.

14     That being said, I do not find that acquiescence is applicable in the context of PPO applications under Part 7 of the Women’s Charter 1961.

15     It must be remembered that family violence typically occurs in the context of our most intimate and personal relationships. There are reasons why one might be hesitant to file an application for a PPO – to quote the Minister of State for Social and Family Development, Sun Xueling (Second Reading of the Women’s Charter (Family Violence and other Matters) (Amendment) Bill (Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official Report (4 February 2023) vol 95):

The third cause as to why family violence is complex is because it often happens behind closed doors which makes it harder to detect. Survivors may hesitate to seek help due to shame, stigma, fear of breaking up their family and the perception that family violence is a personal matter. Similarly, individuals who observe family violence may remain as passive bystanders because they also consider it a private family matter.

[emphasis added]

16     In this vein, I would add that the architecture of the family violence provisions impliedly excludes the application of acquiescence (see also the reasoning of the court in Teh Siew Hua v Tan Kim Chiong [2010] 4 SLR 123 at [46]).[note: 6] For one, there is no time bar as to when an application under Part 7 of the Women’s Charter 1961 may be brought. This is consistent with the various speeches made in Parliament over the years which demonstrate a clear parliamentary intent to encourage victims of family violence to avail themselves of the PPO regime.[note: 7]

17     Second, the sort of conduct that is dealt with by acquiescence is already captured by the requirement of necessity. For example, the court will consider whether the act of family violence is a recent occurrence: XKJ v XKK [2025] SGFC 35 at [46(b)(ii)]. In particular, the courts have declined to issue a PPO where “a significant amount of time had passed (since the family violence) by the time of the hearing”: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [20(b)] citing UNQ v UNR [2020] SGHCF 21 at [38] (more than two years had lapsed); GFS v GFT [2023] SGFC 21 (“GFS”) at [113] (between one to 17 years had lapsed); VFM v VFN [2021] SGFC 91 (“VFM”) (more than two years had lapsed) at [79].

18     For these reasons, I do not find that the equitable defence of acquiescence may be invoked in the context of applications for a PPO under Part 7 of the Women’s Charter 1961. To do so would be to go against the very spirit of those provisions.

Whether the Wife’s application in SS 1306 should be allowed

19     I turn now to first deal with the Wife’s application in SS 1306. The essence of her application is based on the fourth definition of family violence found in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961. Her case is that the Husband had, by his actions, committed continual harassment “with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish” to her.

20     To establish that there was “continual harassment”, the following three requirements must be established (XFL at [37]):

(a)    The respondent has committed “harassment” – i.e., an act of annoying or worrying the applicant by putting pressure on him/her or saying or doing unpleasant things to him/her.

(b)    The harassment is “continual” – i.e., repeated, repetitive.

(c)    The respondent has carried out the continual harassment with the intention or the knowledge that it is likely to cause “anguish” – i.e., severe pain, mental suffering, or unhappiness – to the applicant.

21     I find that the Wife had indeed established, on a balance of probabilities, that the Husband’s conduct over the years, amounted to continual harassment.

22     First, there is the incident in 2015 in which the Wife says the Husband had not only harassed her by saying that he wanted to marry another woman, but that he had also pushed her when she was pregnant, causing her to fall, and subsequently, miscarry.

23     The Husband does not deny having done so. His explanation, rather, is that he cannot be responsible for this because of black magic.[note: 8] I do not accept his explanation. As was noted by the court in Yue Tock Him @ Yee Chok Him v Yee Ee Lim [2011] SGDC 99 at [103], although “[a]llegations of black magic have from time to time been raised in criminal cases…the Courts have not recognised black magic as a defence”. I would also add that insofar as the Husband also says that he is not responsible for what had happened in 2015 because he was “sick and mentally unstable”,[note: 9] he had not adduced any evidence to prove this.

24     In this connection, I would add that the fact that the Husband had pushed the Wife, and caused her to fall (which, as I noted above, he does not deny), would fall within the definition of family violence. By doing so, the Husband had caused hurt to the Wife “by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt”.

25     Second, the Wife also alleges that the Husband would not only insult her, but also use religious teachings to “gaslight” her into thinking that she was “wrong in the eyes of the [r]eligion”.[note: 10]

26     I find that the text messages which the Husband had sent to the Wife did constitute continual harassment.

27     There was a screenshot of a text message from the Husband. The messages show the Husband comparing the Wife to another woman, whom he described as being much “[more] responsible [and] lovely”.[note: 11] The Husband also went on to verbally insult the Wife in the subsequent messages, calling her “selfish”, “irresponsible”, “stupid”, and “stubborn”.

28     In another series of text messages,[note: 12] the Husband had sent some religious teachings to the Wife. To be absolutely clear, I express no view as to the correctness of those religious teachings. What is apparent to me, however, is the Wife’s response: she expressed her frustration with the Husband and made it clear that his conduct was causing her stress, and that if he continued to cause her stress, she would have to speak with her lawyer.

29     Then there is also what the Husband had set out in his own affidavit.[note: 13] He does admit to sending the Wife religious teachings, but with the intention of “being grateful on all that we have achieved” and that the Wife had misconstrued his actions as “harassment”.[note: 14]

30     That being said, as I have noted above (at [28]), the Wife did express her frustration with the Husband sending her religious teachings during a time where she was clearly under immense stress and pressure, and especially when their marital relations were under strain. It is thus apparent, to me, that the Husband must have known that continuing to send her such messages, in these circumstances, would cause her no small amount of unhappiness.

31     I thus find that the Husband’s actions did amount to continual harassment. I also find it likely that the Husband will commit family violence on the Wife in that he will likely continue to harass her. For one, it is clear to me that while both the Husband and the Wife share the same religion, their perspectives are rather different. But it is not this difference that is in issue – rather, it is how the Husband manages and responds to the Wife’s different perspective of their shared religion. For instance, according to the Husband, he can still find no basis, in the religious teachings, for his Wife initiating divorce proceedings.[note: 15]

32     Then there are also several audio recordings. The transcripts of these recordings detail arguments between the Husband and Wife. Those transcripts are telling. They are filled with much bitterness and vitriol. They demonstrate that the Husband lacks a healthy way of expressing the difference in religious viewpoints and is unable to bring himself to find common ground with the Wife.

33     As to the necessity of ordering the PPO, I find that it is indeed necessary to do so in the present case. It appears to me that parties are going through an acrimonious divorce, and as I had observed above, one risk factor in the present case is how the Husband manages and responds to the Wife’s different perspective on their shared religion which in turn, affects how he deals with any conflict that arises between the both of them. It is also apparent to me, and I accept the Wife’s evidence in this regard, that the Husband is not only upset by the pending divorce proceedings, but has acted in a way that affects her negatively.[note: 16]

34     Further, both the Husband and the Wife are still staying together.[note: 17] That they both still continue to share a common space makes it likely that they will continue to interact, and this, in my judgment, increases the risk of further incidents of family violence occurring.

35     In the circumstances, I allow the Wife’s application in SS 1306. In addition, I am also ordering that they both go for counselling.

Whether the Wife’s application in SS 1462 should be allowed

36     I turn now to consider the Wife’s application in SS 1462. She seeks a PPO on behalf of the three children against the Husband. She points to several audio and video recordings which she says demonstrates that the Husband had indeed committed family violence against the children, or that he was indeed likely to do so.[note: 18]

37     In assessing whether the Husband had committed family violence on the children, or was likely to do so, one point I had to consider was whether the “correction exception” applied. That is because the definition of family violence excludes “any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age”. As I had noted in XBC v XBD at [14], the correction exception reflects parliamentary intent to afford parents “a wide degree of discretion when it comes to disciplining their children”.

38     In assessing whether the acts complained of did fall within the correction exception, the court will consider: a) the reasons for the punishment, b) the nature of the punishment and c) the age and personal characteristics of the child: VYB v VYA [2021] SGFC 121 at [14].

39     Of all the video and audio recordings submitted by the Wife, two videos stand out.[note: 19] In the first video, the Husband can be heard shouting angrily at the eldest son. The video also shows a blue, square shaped object, being flung across the ground at the eldest son.

40     The second video shows the Husband aggressively manhandling the eldest son by grabbing his robes and lifting him off the ground in a rough manner.[note: 20] The Husband can be seen raising his voice at and berating the eldest son. The video also shows the Husband taking the prayer mat and hurling it at the eldest son twice.

41     The Wife explained that the Husband was angry with the eldest son for not being properly attired when conducting his prayers. She explained that this was not a one-off occurrence, and that the Husband would scold the children when they did not perform their prayers properly.[note: 21] The Wife also said that she had tried to tell the Husband repeatedly to not discipline the children in this manner, but he had refused to listen to her.[note: 22]

42     In his written submissions, the Husband attempts to downplay the manner in which he had disciplined his eldest son. He says that he had merely lifted the eldest son and put him down.[note: 23]

43     I find that the Husband was indeed likely to commit family violence on the children in such a manner that disentitles him from relying on the correction exception. While the Husband is well within his rights to inculcate religious values in the children, and to correct them when they have veered off course, I find that the manner in which he has chosen to discipline them has gone beyond the pale. In particular, the second video shows the Husband aggressively manhandling the eldest son. I also accept the Wife’s evidence, that the two videos that I have described (above at [39] – [40]), are symptomatic of the discipline which the Husband metes out to the children when they do not perform their prayers properly.

44     I also find it necessary to order the PPO for the three children. It is apparent to me that the Husband has little insight into his own parenting methods, and sees no issues with how he chooses to discipline them. Absent such insight, I consider it likely that the Husband would continue to discipline his children in such a manner.

45     For the reasons I have set out above, the Wife’s application in SS 1462 is allowed. I must emphasise that, in allowing the Wife’s application, I am not making a finding that the Husband is a bad father who does not want the best for the children. What I have found is that the Husband’s methods of disciplining the children, when considered in context of the child’s alleged misbehaviour, crosses the line laid down by the law. I have also found that because the Husband is likely to continue with such methods of disciplining the children, it is necessary to order the PPO.

46     In this connection, I am also ordering that the Husband go for counselling so as to equip him with better methods of disciplining the children.

Whether the Husband’s application in SS 1308 should be allowed

47     The Husband seeks a PPO for himself and the three children against the Wife. He also seeks a DEO to exclude the Wife from the entirety of the matrimonial home.

48     I shall deal first with the Husband’s application for a PPO for himself. I find that the Wife had indeed committed family violence against the Husband, in particular, that she had caused hurt to him “by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt” (to borrow the language of limb b of the definition of family violence set out in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961). I also find it likely that the Wife will commit family violence on the Husband.

49     First, the Wife admitted, in her affidavit and testimony in court,[note: 24] to slapping the Husband on the face. She says that she was frustrated with the Husband because he had gone to someone’s fiancé and asked for her hand in marriage. In my judgment, the Wife’s act of slapping the Husband was an act of family violence in that she ought to have known, minimally, that slapping him would have caused him hurt (ie, bodily pain)[note: 25].

50     Second, there was also the incident on 2 July 2024. The Husband had complained of this incident. He alleges that in this incident, the Wife had hit him 3 – 4 times on the head with her phone. He also alleges that the Wife had spit on him 3 – 4 times.

51     It was disputed as to whether the Wife had used her hands to hit the Husband, or whether she had hit him on the head with her phone. Mr Fernandez had cross-examined the Husband strenuously on this point.[note: 26] It was also hotly disputed whether the Husband had done an X-ray scan to check for any head injuries.[note: 27]

52     I find that the Wife had indeed caused hurt to the Husband in this incident on 2 July 2024. For one, in her affidavit, the Wife did admit to hitting the Husband and spitting at him. She states:[note: 28]

[The Husband] stopped me from leaving the house by standing in front of the door preventing me from leaving the house. This angered me further which caused me to spit at him and hit him.

53     The Wife also confirmed, under cross-examination, that she had indeed hit the Husband and spit at him.[note: 29] She also admitted that she had hurt the Husband in this incident, but explained that she had done so because she wanted to leave the house.[note: 30]

54     In any event, I also find it likely that the Wife will commit family violence on the Husband. It is clear to me that she has built up a deep resentment and anger towards the Husband for how he has treated her over the past 15 years of their marriage. For instance, this was what she had said when the Husband had cross-examined her:[note: 31]

Husband:

I have to remind you that this is affirmed on the 6th September, that you make this statement. So, that’s your answer, okay? Next question, number 17, paragraph number 17. “This angered me further which forced me to spit at him and hit him.” Is that true?

Wife:

Yes, I’ve been controlling this emotion for 15 years throughout our marriage. And where he had been---insult me, threaten me throughout our marriage. So, I have this anger where he do not allow me to leave the house. So---and at the same times, I---I---I was still angry with, you did not helping me in any financial way where I have to face out myself---

Husband:

So, did you---

Wife:

throughout the 15 years of the marriage.

Husband:

Did you hit him? And spit at him?

Wife:

Yes.



55     In addition to this, both incidents, which I have dealt with above, show that the Wife does indeed take out her anger on the Husband. She does not deny slapping and hitting him.

56     As to the necessity of ordering a PPO, I find that it is indeed necessary to do so. The risk factors which I have pointed out above (at [33] – [34]) are equally applicable to the Husband’s case. It was clear to me that their marriage was not a happy one, and this was only exacerbated by the fact that the both of them were unable to communicate their needs and settle their differences in a healthy and productive manner. Given their pending divorce, and the fact that they are still both living together under one roof, this would only create further opportunities for friction and further incidents of family violence.

57     I turn now to consider whether a PPO should be granted in favour of the children.

58     Mr Fernandez argued, in written submissions, that the Wife did not, and was not likely to commit family violence on the children. The first prong of the argument is that the Wife was entitled to rely on the correction exception – that her use of force was justified given that she was disciplining the children.[note: 32] The second prong of the argument is that the Husband never witnessed the past incidents of family violence that he alleges the Wife had committed on the children, and that the injuries he claims they sustained were from the rough and tumble of children playing, and not from any abuse on the Wife’s part.[note: 33]

59     Having examined the evidence, I find that the Wife was indeed likely to commit family violence on the children.

60     In the incident on 2 July 2024, the Wife discovered that the daughter had fallen victim to a scam. The Wife discovered this when she checked her phone bill and found that she had been billed about $500. After questioning the daughter, she discovered that the daughter had shared the one-time password with an unknown person. She also discovered that the daughter had been hiding this from her.[note: 34]

61     The Wife, in her testimony, admitted to slapping the daughter and hitting her on the thigh area with a hanger.[note: 35] It was, however, clear to me that the Wife had done so, not with the intention of disciplining the daughter, but out of sheer anger and frustration. In her own words:[note: 36]

Mr Fernandez:

So, what was the purpose of hitting her with a---at the thigh area and slapping her? What was the purpose?

Wife:

Okay. I was so angry at that time because at that time, uh, I was, uh---uh, one, uh---I think few weeks away to my last day of work. So, I, uh---I’m working only part-time---

Mr Fernandez:

But, Madam, I just want to know what was the purpose of you---

Wife:

Angry.

Mr Fernandez:

You were angry---

Wife:

Because I was frustrated and angry.

Mr Fernandez:

Why were you frustrated and angry?

Wife:

Because I have to pay for $500.

Mr Fernandez:

And---and this is the way you discipline your child?

Wife:

Uh, no, uh---not on this---not on this because that---that time, I was anger due to my financial also. Because it’s like huge amount of $500.



62     Apart from hitting the daughter with a hanger and slapping her, the Wife had also taken a stool, and hurled it at the living room wall. This left a dent in the wall. The Wife admits having thrown the stool at the wall.[note: 37]

63     It was clear to me, from this incident, that the Wife was under strain from having to pay the bills. That the daughter had been the victim of a scam only added to her financial burden. While one can understand the pressures that the Wife must have been facing, this does not, and cannot, condone her actions. It is clear from her own testimony that she had vented her frustration on the daughter by hitting her with the hanger and slapping her. Apart from that, the Wife’s action of hurling the stool at the living room wall, not only spoke to her inability to deal with her frustration, but also demonstrated her disregard for how her actions might frighten her children who had to bear witness to her outward displays of anger.

64     In addition to this, there is also evidence that the Child Protective Services (“CPS”) had become involved in the wake of the incident that had taken place on 2 July 2024.[note: 38] That CPS had become involved, in my judgment, also demonstrated that it was indeed likely that the Wife would commit family violence on the children. The report exhibited in the Wife’s affidavit showed that CPS was concerned with how the Wife had behaved towards the daughter in the incident on 2 July 2024. CPS was also concerned that the children would be triangulated in the conflict between the Husband and Wife.

65     I also find it necessary to order the PPO for the three children. As I have explained, the Wife’s actions were driven by her inability to regulate her emotions and to deal with the stresses she faced. Given the ongoing divorce proceedings, it is likely that the Wife will continue to encounter such pressures in her life. Coupled with her lack of a coping mechanism and proper tools to manage her emotions, it is likely that she may overreact when the children misbehave.

66     To be clear, my finding that the Wife is likely to commit family violence on the children should not, and must not, be taken as an indictment of her as a mother. Simply put, my finding is that the Wife does not have a healthy way of dealing with her own emotions and challenges that she may encounter, and that this was likely to result in her venting her frustration on the children. It may be the case that (and one certainly hopes for such an outcome) both the Husband and the Wife learn how to better manage their emotions and how to interact with their children in a healthy manner. When this day comes, and there is evidence to support such change on the part of the Husband and the Wife, there may certainly be grounds for the PPO to be revoked. Until then, however, a PPO is indeed necessary to ensure that the children are safe.

67     In this vein, I would also order the Husband, the Wife, as well the eldest son and the daughter to go for counselling. Such an order is necessary to ensure that they have the necessary resources to deal with their emotions and the stresses they may face, especially when navigating the ongoing divorce.

68     Finally, I deal with the Husband’s application for a DEO. Based on the evidence before me, I do not find it necessary to order a DEO to exclude the Wife entirely from the matrimonial home. I do not find the Wife to have such a violent temperament such that she needs to be excluded from the matrimonial home to ensure the safety of the Husband as well as the children.

Conclusion

69     In summary, the Wife’s applications in SS 1306 and 1462 are allowed in its entirety. The Husband’s application in SS 1308 for a PPO for himself and the three children are also allowed, but his application for a DEO is dismissed.

70     I shall hear parties on costs.

71     Finally, I conclude with some brief remarks to both the Husband and Wife:

(a)     Stop fighting. You have come to court, and I have made a decision on your applications. Take this opportunity to start afresh. Move on.

(b)     Spare a thought for your children. Your continued conflict at home will only serve to negatively affect them. They are bright children with much potential: I have seen, exhibited in your affidavits, a picture of them receiving Edusave awards. You owe it, to all three of them, to help them realise their potential, and to give them the best possible start in life. You can do so by setting aside your differences and learning to work together.

(c)     Take the counselling seriously. Attend all the scheduled sessions and learn what you can from the counsellor.

[note: 1]Unless otherwise stated, references to provisions of the Women’s Charter are references to the relevant provisions in force prior to 2 January 2025. The definitions of family violence include: (a)wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;(b)causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;(c)wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will;(d)causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member,but does not include any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age.

[note: 2]Wife’s Written Submissions at paragraph 15.

[note: 4]Wife’s Written Submissions at paragraph 28.

[note: 5]For an exposition of “right” and “privilege”, see Wesley N Hohfeld, “Fundamental Legal Conceptions as Applied in Judicial Reasoning” (1917) Yale Law Journal 710.

[note: 6]While legislative amendments were made to the family violence provisions in the Women’s Charter, these amendments do not appear to have affected the basic architecture of the statutory mechanism that provides redress for victims of family violence.

[note: 7]See e.g. Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official Report (5 October 2021) vol 95, Raising Awareness amongst Pharmacists to Spot Signs of Domestic Violence and Teaching Domestic Violence Victims to Seek Help with Non-verbal Cues or Code Words, Minister for Social and Family Development, Mr Masagos Zulkifli. XMZ v XNA

XMZ v XNA
[2025] SGFC 60

Case Number:SS No. 912 of 2024
Decision Date:22 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Husband appeared in person; Clement Yong Hong Kit (M/s Beyond Legal LLC) for the Wife.
Parties: XMZ — XNA

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection – Husband seeking personal protection order against the Wife for the children and himself – Whether the correction exception in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961 is applicable

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection – Husband seeking personal protection order against the Wife for the children and himself – Whether the Wife’s threat to the Husband that she would kill the children and herself amounts to family violence

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection – Husband seeking personal protection order against the Wife for the children and himself – Whether the fact that the Wife loves the children deeply renders personal protection order unnecessary

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection – Husband seeking personal protection order against the Wife for the children and himself – Whether the fact that the Husband is being charged for breach of an expedited order and voluntarily causing harm against the Wife suggests that he is a violent person and is thus not in need of personal protection order

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection – Husband seeking personal protection order against the Wife for the children and himself – Relevance of Wife’s personality and power dynamics between the parties to the issue of personal protection order

22 May 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       This matter involves an application for personal protection order (“PPO”) by a Husband against his Wife. The PPO has been sought to protect the following persons:

(a)     The Husband,

(b)     His son (born in October 2016), and

(c)     His daughter (born in January 2018).

2       To succeed in his PPO application, the Husband must satisfy two requirements on a balance of probabilities.

(a)      First, he must prove that the Wife had committed or is likely to commit “family violence” – defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter (“Charter”) – against the children and himself.

(b)      Second, the Husband must also prove that a PPO is necessary to protect the children and himself from the Wife.

3       The Husband had relied on five incidents to support his PPO application. After a trial, I allowed his application. These are my reasons.

27 July 2023 – Caning and hitting the son

4       I begin with the first incident.

Parties’ case

5       According to the Husband, the Wife had inflicted both “physical and emotional harm on the [son] on 27 July 2023” in the following manner.[note: 1]

(a)      First, she had “verbally abused”, hit, and caned the son because of his poor spelling results. The Husband was not at home at the material time. However, he was able to tender a video recording (obtained from a CCTV camera installed at the home) to prove his claim.

(b)      Second, during the caning, the Wife had injured the son’s left eye and caused it to be bruised and swollen.

6       The Wife’s case is as follows:[note: 2]

(a)      First, she was not at home on 27 July 2023 from 9.00 am to 4.00 pm. At the material time, she was attending a lecture for her nursing course. She adduced an “attendance” table from the course website to support this claim.[note: 3]

(b)     That said, the Wife did not deny that she was the person shown in the video recording. She explained that (i) she was disciplining the son at the material time, (ii) she had used only 10% to 15% of her strength during the caning,[note: 4] and (iii) her actions did not constitute family violence.

(c)      Finally, the Wife vehemently denied having injured the son’s eye. She adduced a medical report (dated 30 July 2023) which stated that it was the daughter who had accidentally poked the son’s eye with a plastic stick while playing with him.[note: 5]

My decision

7       Given the positions taken by the parties, the issues regarding the 27 July incident are as follows:

(a)     Did the incident shown in the video recording take place on 27 July 2023?

(b)     Did the Wife’s actions towards the son – as shown in the recording – come within the correction exception of “family violence” (“correction exception”)?

(c)     Did the Wife injure the son’s eye?

Incident had occurred on 27 July 2023

8       Regarding first issue, I find that the incident shown in the video recording did take place on 27 July 2023. These are my reasons:

(a)      First, the Wife had admitted that she is the person shown in the recording. The timestamp in the recording shows the date and time as 27 July 2023 and 3.50 pm respectively. The timestamp contradicts the Wife’s case that she was attending a lecture – and not at home – at the material time.

(b)     The Wife claimed that the Husband had tampered with the recording. I am unable to accept this claim. The recording was made about 10 months before the Husband decided to apply for the PPO against the Wife.[note: 6] There is simply no reason why he would want to tamper with the timestamp at the material time.

(c)      Second, one day after the incident (i.e., on 28 July 2023), the Husband had sent a WhatsApp message to the Wife. In that message, he had told her that it was “not right” for her to “continuously hit” the son “yesterday”. In her replies via WhatsApp, the Wife did not deny having hit the child on 27 July 2023. She instead defended her actions.[note: 7]

Wife had committed family violence – Correction exception inapplicable

9       This brings me to the second (and more important) issue. The Wife’s acts of hitting and caning the son would technically qualify as family violence. Does such conduct come within the correction exception?

10     On this issue, s 64 of the Charter provides that family violence “does not include any force lawfully used … by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age”. In XKJ v XKK [2025] SGFC 35 (“XKJ”) at [32], I had explained that to successfully invoke the correction exception, a respondent must prove two things.

(a)      First, the respondent must prove that the use of force was intended to benefit the child – i.e., to inculcate in the child the appropriate behaviour and attitude (i) in his/her conduct as a person and (ii) in his/her relationship with others.

(b)      Second, the respondent must also prove that the use of force is neither excessive nor unreasonable.

11     Has the Wife satisfied the first requirement? In my view, the answer is yes.

(a)     As a preliminary point, I note that the Wife had given conflicting reasons for caning the son.

(i)        One day after the incident (i.e., on 28 July 2023), the Wife sent the following WhatsApp messages to the Husband to explain why she had used force on the son:[note: 8]

Message sent at 10.57 am – “I hit him Cauz he said that study is boring and crying to do (sic) homework”.

Message sent at 11.02 am – “... I hit him for his direspect (sic) behaviour and everyday crying to do (sic) homework”.

It appears from the above that the Wife had used force on the son for two reasons. First, for his poor attitude towards his studies. Second, for showing “disrespectful behaviour”.

(ii)       During the trial (i.e., about 17 months after the incident), the Wife gave different reasons for having used force on the son on 23 July 2023. Initially, she testified that it was because he had lied to her.[note: 9] Upon further examination, the Wife testified that it was because the son had copied during spelling.[note: 10]

(b)     I find that each of the Wife’s reasons given on 28 July 2023 and during the trial can provide a basis for punishing the son. Specifically, I am prepared to accept her evidence (i) that the son had been showing a poor attitude towards his studies, (ii) that he done badly in a recent spelling assignment, (iii) that he had copied during spelling, and (iv) that he thus needed to be disciplined.

12     Next, has the Wife satisfied the second requirement to the correction exception? In my view, the answer is no. This is because while she had begun the punishment with an intention to correct the son’s attitude and behaviour, the video recording clearly shows that the execution of her punishment was later fuelled by anger. It is settled law that the use of force on a child in such circumstances falls outside of the correction exception: see XKJ at [32(d)]. Evidence that the Wife had punished the son out of anger include the following:

(a)      First, at the beginning of the punishment, the Wife had screamed repeatedly, and her demeanour was filled with rage. The son can be seen to be genuinely fearful of her at the material time. Indeed, during the hearing, I observed that the Wife was herself visibly distressed when reviewing the video recording of the punishment.

(b)      Second, the Wife continued to cane the son even though the latter had apologised for his misbehaviour.[note: 11]

(c)      Finally, there was a lull period in the punishment.[note: 12] At about 4.18 pm, the Wife suddenly broke the lull by beginning to cane the son again for no apparent reason. Apart from venting the Wife’s simmering frustration, the caning does not appear to serve any other function.

No evidence that the Wife had injured the son’s eye

13     The remaining issue is whether the Wife had injured the son’s eye while caning him.

14     Regarding this issue, I note the following.

(a)      First, there is no evidence – either from the video recording[note: 13] or testimony from the son – to prove that the Wife had caused the injury.

(b)      Second, there are two medical reports which contradict the Husband’s claim that the Wife had injured the son’s eye. The first report is based on a consultation about three days after 27 July 2023. (This report is adduced by the Wife.) The second report is based on a consultation about one week prior to 5 August 2023. (This report is tendered by the Husband.)[note: 14] Both medical reports suggested that the son’s eye injury was caused “accidentally” by a plastic stick.

15     Despite the above, the Husband submitted that the Wife had injured the son’s eye. The sole basis for this submission is that she had failed to deny such an assertion that is implicit in the following message that he had sent to her one day after the caning incident.[note: 15]

[The son] don’t (sic) deserved to get hit that back (sic) like yest, till hurt his eyes and etc.

[emphasis and text in square brackets added]

16     I am unable to accept the Husband’s submission.

(a)     I find that the accusation in the message – that the Wife had injured the son’s eye – is indirect and equivocal. Such an accusation could easily have been missed by her.

(b)     Indeed, the Wife explained that she did not agree or deny the message because she was more focused at the material time on highlighting to the Husband that he had failed to take any responsibility to guide and discipline the children.[note: 16]

(c)     Finally, during cross-examination, the Husband had acknowledged that the Wife did not admit to having injured the son’s eye in her replies to the implicit accusation in the message.[note: 17]

2 April 2024 – Threat to kill the children – Repeated messages to the Husband

17     I now move on to the next incident. It had occurred on 2 April 2024. The following facts regarding that incident are not disputed:

(a)     The Husband had suspected that the Wife was having an affair with X. To gather evidence of this, he had installed a voice recorder at the home without her knowledge.

(b)     On 2 April 2024, via phone call over WhatsApp, the Wife had an argument with the Husband regarding the voice recorder.

(c)     At or around 7.01 pm that day, the Wife sent a message to the Husband stating, “im going to kill myself with my kids” (“Threat over WhatsApp”).[note: 18]

(d)     Shortly after receiving the message, the Husband reached home. The Wife held a knife and threatened to cut herself (“Threat at Home”). She wanted the Husband to disclose his evidence of the alleged affair. After a tense moment, the situation was defused. The Husband had a voice recording of the Threat at Home.[note: 19]

Parties’ case

18     The parties disagreed about the circumstances of the Threat over WhatsApp and the Threat at Home.

(a)     According to the Husband –

(i)       The Wife had made both threats to compel him to produce his evidence of the alleged affair.

(ii)       The Threat at Home was made in the presence of the children and had caused them to be alarmed.[note: 20]

(b)     According to the Wife[note: 21] –

(i)       She had made the Threat over WhatsApp under the pressure of the Husband’s accusations of her having an affair. Specifically, he had kept “pushing and bullying her” to admit to the affair. During a WhatsApp phone call that day, he had even asked her to “go and die”.

(ii)       As for the Threat at Home, the Wife agreed that her intention was to compel the Husband to produce the recording. When making this threat, the children were not present.

(iii)       It is the Wife’s case that a threat to commit suicide did not constitute “family violence”.[note: 22] This is because she did not cause hurt to the Husband and the children at the material time. She did not wilfully or knowingly place them in fear of hurt. In any event, she did not intend to carry out the threats. If the Husband had played the recording, she would not have made the threats.

19     Given the parties’ position, the factual issues for determination are as follows.

(a)      First, did the Wife send the Threat over WhatsApp under pressure from the Husband?

(b)      Second, were the children present when the Threat at Home was made?

(c)      Finally, did the Wife commit family violence by making the threats?

My decision

Wife did not send the Threat over WhatsApp under pressure

20     Regarding the first issue, I am unable to the Wife’s claim that she was pressured into sending the Threat over WhatsApp because the Husband had (a) “bullied” her to admit to the affair and (b) asked her to “go and die”.

21     The records show the following communication between the parties shortly before the Threat over WhatsApp was sent:[note: 23]
