html:
XMN v XMO

XMN v XMO
[2025] SGFC 54

Case Number:SS 2420 of 2024
Decision Date:15 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Wife in person and unrepresented; The Husband in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XMN — XMO

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

15 May 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       The whole purpose of the family violence regime, as instantiated by the relevant provisions of the Women’s Charter 1961, is to protect those who find themselves trapped in the cycle of domestic abuse. To that end, any orders which are made, are made with only one purpose in mind, and that is to protect. These orders, for example, a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) or the Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”) are not meant to punish Respondents to such applications, and that much is made clear by the jurisprudence of the Family Courts (for example, see the case of WSD v WSE [2024] SGFC 1).

2       SS 2420/2024 (“SS 2420”) was the Wife’s application for a PPO for herself and the two children against the Husband. She also sought a DEO to exclude the Husband entirely from their residential property. The incident which formed the basis of the Wife’s application had taken place on 12 December 2024. The Husband had suspected her of cheating on him. There was an argument. In the midst of this argument, the Husband had taken a knife to threaten the Wife. The police were called. The Husband was arrested and subsequently released on bail.

3       I heard the trial of the matter on 21 March 2025 and allowed the Wife’s application in SS 2420. These are the reasons for my decision.

4       An Applicant seeking a PPO must establish the following two requirements on a balance of probabilities.

5       The first is that there was an act of family violence as defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961,[note: 1] or that it was likely that the Respondent would commit family violence.

6       The second requirement is that the PPO is necessary for the protection of the family member in question.

7       In the present case, I found it likely that the Husband would commit family violence on Wife as well as the two children. The Wife had adduced text messages to show that the Husband had lost control and severely caned his son. It is clear from these text messages,[note: 2] which the Husband had sent to the Wife on the 3rd of December 2024, that he had indeed lost control and caned his son.

8       During his testimony, the Husband did not dispute that he had lost control. In fact, he went on to say that he estimated that he had hit his son about 20 to 30 times.[note: 3]

9       Apart from this incident, in the incident on the 12th of December 2024, the Husband had admitted to stabbing the knife, which was a rather large knife (with a blade that was 17cm long),[note: 4] onto the table in a fit of rage:[note: 5]

Husband:

So, I go down and take the knife out. I didn’t hide the knife. I told the police, “You scan the knife. If got a single ounce of bath soap or anything, you catch me.” I didn’t hide the knife. I let my daughter saw but maybe she remember the wrong timing. I go down take the knife out. I pass to her. Asked her, “You want to commit suicide? Commit suicide.” She refuses. She keep asking me to kill her. I got so angry, I take the knife, I stab on the table then I realised that it’s a bit dangerous. I took the knife. I asked my son to keep it. My son came out, he keep---he kept the knife. Then she continued to take her eyebrow trimmer to try and commit suicide. I look at it, I thought that she is just joking, lah. The eyebrow trimmer, the blade is like maybe the size of a toothpick. It is a very small blade. I just think that she’s just joking, lah. Then I tell her, “Eh, like that won’t die one. You want to die, go and take the iron pills.” I said it as a joke.

[emphasis added]



10     It is thus apparent to me from these 2 incidents, and the manner in which the Husband had described his account of these incidents, that he does have difficulty in controlling his temper, and that he is prone to violent outbursts.

11     In addition, it is also clear that the Husband is not above resorting to means to manipulate those that he purports to love to do his bidding. He had given evidence of how he had devised means of getting the Wife to have sex with him. He would pretend to cheat on her by hiring escorts to make her jealous as he realised that if he could make her jealous, she would be willing to have sex with him. As he explained:[note: 6]

Husband:

As for the---as for what she said about the sex thing, when she’s angry, she cut off sex for 1 whole year. The only time that she re-established sex is when she realised that I was contacting my ex-girlfriend. And it wasn’t for any bad things. I just contacted her to say thank you for what happened 4 years ago, okay. She was so jealous that she had sex with me. So, I thought that every time I make her jealous, she will have sex with me. So, I tell her say I visit prostitute. She refuse to believe me because all the accounts, all the bank accounts are joint accounts, she have access to them and she can where the money goes. And she knows that I didn’t spend a single cent. So, I cannot be visiting prostitutes. So, I ran out on [inaudible] I thought of the best idea I can come up with, right, is just to ask my maid. Because my maid is her best friend. My maid has been with us 7 plus years. If I want to have some hanky panky with my maid, I won’t wait 7 years later, okay. As for the prostitute in Taiwan when we go on a Taiwan trip, she say that I---I go and find a prostitute. Yes, I did find a prostitute but I paid the prostitute to say that we have sex but I didn’t have sex with the prostitute. Why? Because when I come back home, she knows this very well, I have sex with her. I’m [X] years old this year, [Y] years old. I cannot have sex 2 consecutive times one. I keep telling her this now. All that I say in the past is just trying to make her jealous so that she have sex with me, and it’s true. She---she---she got so jealous, she started to started to start a tracking system to track how many time we had sex in month. So, my plan worked. You can check her phone. That is for the sex thing, I have never cheated on my wife. But it’s very difficult, I don’t know if you all can understand, that when a wife withhold sex for 1 whole year, is very difficult for a man to try to control. And this is why I come up with these funny ideas.



12     Apart from this, there is one other point, and that was the Husband’s need for control. It was apparent to me that the Husband was very paranoid about the possibility that the Wife may have cheated on him. The Husband spoke of how he had established a system with the Wife after he suspected her of cheating on him with his friend from the army. Under this system, he would be able to video call the Wife to check on her. And if the Wife had missed this call, she had to call him back immediately.

13     That the Husband established such a system spoke volumes as to his mindset. I found it to be the case that the Husband expected the Wife to comply, and that if she did not do so, there would be consequences. Indeed, the lengths which the Husband went to, to check on whether the Wife had been cheating on him on the 12th of December 2024, spoke to the depths of his paranoia and his need for control. For example, he had asked the Wife to remove her underwear to “check for any signs of sex”.[note: 7] In this connection, I also believe the Wife’s account: that the Husband had indeed told her that if he could not have her, then nobody else could.[note: 8]

14     Taken together, the evidence before me painted a picture of a man who was not only controlling, but manipulative and prone to violent outbursts. It was also evident that his actions had negatively impacted those he claimed to hold most dear – the Wife’s testimony spoke to how she had tolerated his behaviour for many years, and how matters had, for her, finally reached a breaking point. This also made it apparent that the Husband had little to no self-awareness on his part. Given this, I concluded that it was indeed likely that the Husband would commit family violence on the Wife, as well as the two children.

15     For completeness, I would add that while much was made of how the Husband may have had an underlying psychiatric condition, namely, borderline personality disorder (“BPD”), there was nothing on the evidence before me (ie, in the form of a doctor’s report) to indicate that this was indeed the case. That being said, I have concluded (above at [7] – [14]) that there were indeed very troubling aspects of the Husband’s personality and behaviour which pointed to the likelihood of him committing family violence on the Wife and children.

16     I must emphasise that the law does not require an Applicant to prove that family violence had actually been committed. It suffices to show that family violence is likely to be committed, and that is set out in the words of s 65 of the Women’s Charter 1961: XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [19].

17     Having found that the Husband was indeed likely to commit family violence, I turned to consider whether it was necessary to grant the PPO. In this vein, the law also says that once it is found that the Respondent is likely to commit family violence, a PPO is presumptively necessary: XJB v XJC [2025] SGFC 21 at [121] citing XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [21(a)] citing Lai Kwok Kin v Teo Zien Jackson [2020] 5 SLR 389 at [39].

18     On the evidence before me, and leaving aside any presumption, I am indeed satisfied that a PPO was necessary to protect both the Wife and the children and that is because of the Husband’s uncontrolled displays of anger. There were, at least on the evidence before me, two examples of him doing so, in relation to him caning his son as well as him stabbing the knife onto the desk in a fit of anger.

19     The risk of family violence, in my judgment, was further increased when one took into account the Husband’s controlling and manipulative personality.

20     In addition, I also found it necessary to order a DEO to exclude the Husband from the entire property. Physical separation was necessary to ensure the safety of the Wife as well as the two children. This is especially since the Husband had not only displayed a propensity for uncontrolled displays of violence, but had also told the Wife that if he could not have her, nobody else could.[note: 9]

21     I thus allowed the Wife’s application in SS 2420. In the circumstances, I also ordered that both the Wife and the Husband were to attend counselling.

22     Given that the Wife did not seek costs of her application, I made no order as to costs.

[note: 1]References to provisions of the Women’s Charter 1961 are references to the provisions in force prior to 2 January 2025.

XMQ v XMP

XMQ v XMP
[2025] SGFC 55

Case Number:Maintenance Summons No. 1077 of 2024
Decision Date:14 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Marcus Ho
Counsel Name(s): Mohamed Fazal Bin Abdul Hamid (I.R.B Law LLP) for the complainant; The respondent in person.
Parties: XMQ — XMP

Family Law – Maintenance – Child

14 May 2025

District Judge Marcus Ho:

Introduction

1       The Complainant is 29 years old this year. The Respondent is 32 years old this year. The Complainant and the Respondent never married. They were in a relationship when they were teenagers but have not been in touch since sometime in 2011.

2       On 8 May 2024, the Complainant filed an application for maintenance for her child who is 13 years old this year (the “Child”). At the start of the trial, the Respondent took the position that the Child was not his biological child. This was subsequently resolved by way of a paternity test, after which the Respondent accepted that he was the biological father of the Child. I hereinafter refer to the Complainant as the “Mother” and the Respondent as the “Father”.

3       Having heard the parties’ evidence on 24 October 2024 and their submissions on 7 February 2025, I ordered the Father to pay the Mother a sum of $750 per month as maintenance for the Child, as well as a total sum of $6,750 as backdated maintenance for the Child. I also ordered the Father to pay costs of the proceedings fixed at $500.

4       The Father has since filed an appeal against my orders relating to the maintenance payable for the Child as well as my orders relating to the backdated maintenance ordered. I now set out the grounds of my decision.

Preliminary issue

5       On 7 February 2025, just before parties were asked to provide their oral submissions on the matter, the Father requested to furnish some documents purporting to show that the Mother was living a luxurious life, changing new cars, and carrying branded bags, including one that he said cost about $15,000. I did not allow these documents. By this time, both parties had already given their testimony on the witness stand, completing their evidence on 24 October 2024. The Father did not inform the Mother ahead of time of his intention to provide these documents, and offered no satisfactory explanation as to why he did not put forth this evidence any earlier.

Legal requirements

6       Section 69(2) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (the “Charter”) provides that the court may order maintenance for a child on due proof that a parent has neglected or refused to provide reasonable maintenance for the child. In making its determination, the court is to have regard to all the circumstances of the case, including the financial needs of the child, and the income and financial resources of the parties.

The parties’ cases

7       The Mother sought payment of $750 per month as maintenance for the child. In addition, she sought backdated maintenance of $1,500 per month for a period of 200 months. The Mother estimated the Child’s monthly expenses to be about $1,900 per month, but sought $750 per month as this was what she believed the Father would be able to afford. The backdated maintenance was calculated based on what the Mother calculated to be the amount she had spent on the Child since his birth.

8       The Father objected to the Mother’s application. The Father says that he is unable to afford the maintenance sought by the Mother. The Father proposed to contribute $200 to $250 per month, being what he says is the maximum he can afford.[note: 1]

Maintenance for the Child

The Child’s reasonable expenses

9       I first considered what the Child’s reasonable expenses were. The Mother claimed that the Child’s reasonable expenses amount to about $1,900 per month. Her list of the Child’s estimated monthly expenses is as follows:

10     The Father did not specifically dispute the Mother’s estimates, nor did he cross-examine her on these expenses. In my assessment, the Child’s reasonable expenses amounted to approximately $1,800 per month, which was not far from the figure estimated by the Mother. To explain:

(a)     I assessed the Child’s reasonably monthly expenses to be about $120 lower than that estimated by the Mother as I felt that the Child’s medical fees and clothing expenses were too high and were not supported by the objective evidence.

(b)     While the amount spent on food and groceries at $1,000 per month seemed a little high, I accepted that the Mother’s circumstances in raising the Child as a single parent may have placed certain limitations on the extent of care that she could provide for the Child, which may have consequently necessitated such higher costs. For example, not having the time to prepare home-cooked meals for the Child may have resulted in her spending more to buy meals home or to have food delivered.

(c)     Similarly, I accepted that juggling two jobs may have left the Mother with less time and energies to coach the Child at home or to help him through his academic work. I therefore found her estimated expenses of $280 per month on enrichment and tuition classes for the Child to be justified.

The parties’ incomes

11     I next considered the parties’ finances. The Mother worked two jobs, one as a part-time administrative assistant earning $1,500 per month, and the other from a cloud kitchen she owned, where she received a salary of $2,000 per month. In total, the Mother claims to earn an income of $3,500 per month. The Father did not dispute this. I found that the Mother’s position was more or less supported by the payslips and bank account statements she provided. I therefore accepted that she earned $3,500 per month for the purposes of this application.

12     The Father ran a canteen stall at a secondary school. He indicated in his statement that his monthly income was $2,500,[note: 2] but at trial he claimed to earn about $2,000 to $2,300 per month, with the latter figure being what he might earn in a “good month”.[note: 3] However, this was not supported by the documentary evidence provided, and I was not convinced that the Father only earned up to $2,300 per month.

13     The Father’s IRAS Notice of Assessment for the Year of Assessment 2024 showed that he earned $2,536.08 per month on average in the latest year of assessment.[note: 4] While the Father asserted that this amount included what he earned from driving that year, he offered no objective evidence showing this to be the case. Even if this did comprise some supplementary income he earned from private hire driving, I saw no good reason why this could not continue.

14     Further, the Father testified at trial that he paid his stall assistant about $2,400 to $2,600 per month. Again, he did not provide any documents showing this. I found it inconceivable that he would pay his employee more than he claimed to take home for himself. If this was indeed the case, he may well be financially better off working as a stall assistant instead.

15     On the balance of the evidence, for the purposes of this application, I found that the Father earned a minimum monthly income of $2,500. I accordingly adopted this figure to derive the income ratio between the parties at 58% to 42% in the Mother’s favour.

My decision

16     Applying this ratio to what I had found to be the Child’s reasonable expenses at $1,800, I found that the Father’s share would amount to about $750 per month.

17     The Father declared personal monthly expenses of $2,276.[note: 5] He said that he would be unable to meet the monthly maintenance payments sought by the Mother as he has various financial obligations arising from his prospective marriage and his father’s medical condition.

18     I did not find the Father’s claims to be made out on the evidence provided:

(a)     The Father’s declared monthly expenses included an amount of $1,000 per month as allowance for his parents. However, there was no proof that he would withdraw this amount in cash to pay to his parents each month. His mother continued to work and operate a canteen stall in the same school as the Father, and there was no proof that his parents needed or expected this much from him, considering that this amounted to more than 40% of what he says he earned. there was also no proof that his parents needed this money, particularly when his mother continued to work and operate a canteen stall in the same school as the Father. The Father also did not provide any evidence showing his father’s medical condition, or of the costs incurred by his father for his medical condition, such as to justify this amount of $1,000.

(b)     It was also clarified at trial that the Father’s estimates for his expenses on conservancy charges and internet, as stated in his list of expenses, were estimates for a household of four. His own share of these two expenses should therefore only be $69 instead of $276.

(c)     The Father also did not provide any evidence showing the extent to which his prospective marriage impinged on his ability to pay any maintenance ordered. The Father said that his flat was “coming next year”[note: 6], but did not provide any indication of the financial outlay required, or of his partner’s ability to contribute to this undertaking.

19     I accordingly found that the Father would be able to meet the maintenance payments of $750 per month if he were to make some adjustments to his own lifestyle and expenditure. The Mother herself would have had to make sacrifices and adjustments to her own lifestyle to meet her financial obligations, not least the expenses of the Child, who was born of both parties, but for the past 13 years has been the Mother’s sole responsibility.

20     As the Father had not made any financial contributions towards the Child, I found in the circumstances of the case that he had neglected to provide reasonable maintenance for the Child and that it was reasonable to order that he pays the Mother a sum of $750 per month as maintenance for the Child. I ordered this to be paid on the 21st day of each month, with effect from 21 February 2025.

21     However, I did not find it appropriate to order backdated maintenance of the amounts and for the duration sought by the Mother. On the Mother’s own account, it was only in February 2024 that she obtained the Father’s contact. It appeared that it was only thereafter that she attempted to seek maintenance from him, in part motivated by her family’s financial situation. The Mother’s evidence was in fact that she could not and did not contact the Father after the Child was born, and it was not disputed that the Father had blocked her on WhatsApp and on Facebook. The Mother could have brought an application for maintenance at any time and did not satisfactorily explain why she had not done so earlier. In fact, I noted that when the parties met about three or four years after the Child was born, the Mother’s then-husband expressly told the Father to stay away from her and the Child,[note: 7] which reasonably gave rise to the Father’s impression that the Mother wanted nothing more from him in relation to the Child. I therefore did not find it fair to make the Father responsible for the expenses the Child had incurred prior to the application, where the circumstances were such that he would have reasonably assumed that the Mother did not want or require any such contribution from him.

22     However, despite having notice of the Mother’s intentions and of the Child’s needs since the commencement of this application, the Father did not make any contributions to the Child’s expenses, even if only of the amounts of $200 to $250 per month that he said he was able pay. I therefore ordered that the maintenance orders be backdated to May 2024, when the Mother commenced this application. Taking into account the Father’s financial resources, I ordered that the total arrears of $6,750 (being the arrears accrued from May 2024 to January 2025) shall be paid in instalments of $250 per month, payable on the 21st day of each month with effect from 21 February 2025.

Conclusion

23     The Mother sought costs from the Father of between $2,000 to $2,500. The Father objected to this, reasoning that he was unable to afford this. I found that some costs would be payable by the Father to the Mother, bearing in mind the delay occasioned by the Father’s insistence that he was not the biological father of the Child, and the fact that the quantum of monthly maintenance sought by the Mother was reasonable and ultimately aligned with what I ordered. However, I did not find it appropriate to order the full amount sought by the Mother as she was substantially unsuccessful in the bulk of her claim relating to backdated maintenance, which I did not find to be reasonable. I therefore ordered costs of $500 payable by the Father to the Mother. To give the Father more time to pay, given his new obligations, I ordered that this amount of $500 be payable by 28 February 2025.

XIE v XIF

XIE v XIF
[2025] SGFC 50

Case Number:Divorce No 4805 of 2021 (Summons No 3502 of 2024)
Decision Date:05 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Faustina Joyce Fernando, Linda Joelle Ong (Engelin Teh Practice LLC) for the plaintiff; Eileen Lim (OTP Law Corporation) for the defendant.
Parties: XIE — XIF

Family Law – Procedure – Costs

5 May 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       This is my decision on the costs of SUM 3502/2024 (“SUM 3502”) which was the Husband’s application for discovery and interrogatories. The substantive decision in respect of the Husband’s application can be found in XIE v XIF [2025] SGFC 22.

2       Counsel for the Wife argues that costs should be reserved to the Judge hearing the substantive variation application in SUM 2713/2024 (“SUM 2713”). Their argument is premised on the merits of SUM 3502 being inextricably linked to the merits of the variation application.[note: 1] In that vein, counsel for the Wife argues that the Judge hearing SUM 2713 is best placed to “decide if the documents and information” that the Husband had sought were necessary for the fair disposal of the variation application.[note: 2]

3       In addition, counsel for the Wife also argued that she ran the risk of “severe prejudice” if she was ordered to pay costs now and the variation application in SUM 2713 was dismissed, and the hearing Judge did not “deem it necessary to consider [her] income and expenses documents”.[note: 3]

4       On the other hand, counsel for the Husband argued that he should be entitled to costs given that he had succeeded in SUM 3502. However, counsel for the Husband argued that costs should be awarded on an indemnity basis, fixed at $4132.40 (all-in), as her withholding of these “standard documents and information” was “manifestly unreasonable” and had caused needless delay and wasted resources.[note: 4] Counsel for the Husband also argues that the Wife had adopted an adversarial stance by refusing to reasonably disclose the documents sought, which necessitated the application in SUM 3502.

5       Costs should not, in my judgment, be reserved to the hearing Judge in the present case. I do not agree with the arguments advanced by counsel for the Wife. Their premise is that the merits of SUM 3502 are inextricably linked to the merits of the variation application in in SUM 2713. This argument, when driven to its natural conclusion, would mean that costs for applications for discovery and interrogatories, must always be reserved to the hearing Judge.

6       That cannot be right. In assessing the merits of SUM 2713, the hearing Judge is not, as counsel for the Wife sought to suggest, assessing whether the discovery and interrogatories were indeed necessary for the fair disposal of the matter.[note: 5] While the hearing Judge may find, or express the view, that certain documents produced in discovery did not factor into their decision, this does not necessarily mean that the application for discovery and interrogatories had been unreasonably taken out. After all, the provision of documents and answers through discovery and interrogatories also enables the requesting party to formulate their position in relation to the substantive dispute.

7       Given that the Husband had indeed succeeded in his application, he is entitled to costs, which I fix at $1632.40 (all-in).[note: 6] These costs are to be paid to the Husband by 9 June 2025.

8       In arriving at this quantum, I considered the number of items sought, and that the written submissions and hearing before me were relatively short. In particular, I also took into account the fact that the Wife did have ample opportunities to make voluntary disclosure of these documents, which would not only have avoided the need for SUM 3502, but would also have facilitated mediation which may well have borne fruit. This was, in my judgment, a factor warranting an upward adjustment in the quantum of costs.

[note: 1]Wife’s Written Submissions at para 7.

[note: 2]Wife’s Written Submissions at para 6.

[note: 3]Wife’s Written Submissions at para 6.

[note: 4]Husband’s Written Submissions at paras 3 – 7.

[note: 5]See Wife’s Written Submissions at para 6(b) which states: “The hearing judge determining the variation application will be best placed to decide if the documents and information sought were necessary for the fair disposal of the variation application in the first place. If the variation application is dismissed, the Plaintiff should be entitled to the costs of both applications.”.

[note: 6]The disbursements, according to counsel for the Husband, came up to $132.40: Husband’s Written Submissions at para 8.

XMB v XMA

XMB v XMA
[2025] SGFC 52

Case Number:Summons No. SS 2803 of 2024
Decision Date:08 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Amy Tung
Counsel Name(s): Low Zhi Liang, Gabriel (Tan Lee & Partners) for the Complainant; Kannan Nadarajan & Dilys H Chua (CHP Law LLC) for the Respondent.
Parties: XMB — XMA

Family Law – Family Violence – Orders for Protection

8 May 2025

Judgment reserved

District Judge Amy Tung:

1       The Parties before me have been engaged in lengthy legal proceedings since the Mother filed the divorce writ in 2021. This application for a personal protection order (PPO) was filed by the Father on behalf of the three (3) children of the marriage, C1, C2 and C3 on 4 November 2024, at the doorstep of the hearing of the ancillary matters (AMs) fixed on and heard by me on 19 December 2024. The circumstances as to why the application was filed and the procedural history of the divorce proceedings are relevant and would be set out at the appropriate portions of this judgment.

Background and History of the Parties

2       The Mother left the matrimonial home with the 3 children on 23 May 2021. On 9 July 2021, the Father took the eldest child, C1 from his school and since then C1 has been living with the Father at the matrimonial home to date.

3       Both Parents filed for interim care and control of the 3 children; the Mother filed her application on 11 April 2022 while the Father filed his application on 11 May 2022. Both applications were heard on 27 July 2022 with the decision rendered on 29 July 2022. The Father was granted interim care and control of C1 while the Mother was granted interim care and control of C2 and C3.[note: 1] Access orders were made such that each parent was to take access of the child/children not under her/his respective care and control on alternate weekends. In line with therapeutic justice principles, both parents were asked to attend the session during which the Court delivered its decision. I explained to the parents that I was prepared to let status quo remains so as not to cause a destabilising situation for C1 in view of his near and upcoming Primary School Leaving Examinations (PSLE). The parents were also strongly encouraged to step away from their litigious mindset to focus on preparing C1 for the PSLE and giving him the necessary moral and emotional support.

4       The access arrangements went on thereafter for over 1 ½ years while the case was being managed and prepared for hearing on the AMs by the case conferencing team. Sometime from February 2024, access for both parents ceased and regrettably, they have not had any access to the child/children not under their respective interim care and control since then.

5       The AMs were originally fixed for hearing before me on 23 October 2024. However, that hearing had to be converted into a case conference as the appointed Child Representative wrote in to Court to inform that he was not able to prepare his report given that he had not been able to meet up with either the Father or C1.

6       At the case conference, the former counsel for the Father informed the Court that the Father would be “overseas until next year to serve God’s purposes with his body and soul”. When I enquired as to where C1 was at that time, I was informed that the Father had refused to let his counsel communicate with the Court on that. Upon the Court’s insistence and direction, counsel for the Father subsequently informed that from what he knew, C1 should be in Singapore.

7       Given that there was some concern as to C1’s care and living arrangements (based on the information given that the Father was overseas until next year) and his emotional state, I directed that C1 be produced in Court for counselling and check-in by our Court Family Specialist on 25 October 2024 (PM). I provided instructions that C1 may be accompanied to Court by one of his school teachers.

8       On 24 October 2024 (one day before C1 was to attend before the Court Family Specialist), the Mother turned up at the matrimonial home. Both the Father and C1 were present at the matrimonial home. There appeared to be an altercation between the Mother and C1, leading to alleged injuries to C1. Less than 2 weeks later, the Father filed this present application on 4 November 2024 seeking a PPO for all 3 children.

The present application

9       Before this Court, the Father relied on seven (7) incidents to mount the case for a PPO on behalf of the children against the Mother.[note: 2] For ease of reference, I shall use the same headings as the Father in his affidavit of evidence-in-chief (“AEIC”) in listing out the 7 incidents: -

(a)     Threatened family with a knife on 3 May 2020;

(b)     Removal and restraint of the children on 23 May 2021;

(c)     No medical attention provided to sick children on 18 February 2024;

(d)     Self-harm and assault on 20 February 2024;

(e)     Breaking and entering on 22 February 2024;

(f)     Removal of C2 and C3 on 8 March 2024;

(g)     Violence against C1 on 24 October 2024.

10     The Father has two witnesses, being his mother, Madam [T] and C1. The Mother has one other witness, a family friend known as [S].

11     Before going into each of the incident relied by the Father, I shall set out the law in brief governing this application; that being the law in place before the new amendments under the Women’s Charter (Family Violence and Other Matters) (Amendment) Act 2023 came into effect on 2 January 2025. The then section 65(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“WC”) states that: -

65.-(1)    The Court may, upon satisfaction on a balance of probabilities that family violence has been committed or is likely to be committed against a family member and that it is necessary for the protection of the family member, make a protection order restraining the person against whom the order is made from using family violence against the family member.

12     Both limbs of section 65 must be satisfied before the Court will grant a PPO:-

(a)     The person against whom the PPO application is made has committed or is likely to commit family violence; and

(b)     It is necessary for the PPO to be granted for the protection of the person seeking protection or the person on whose behalf the protection is sought.

13     Under the then section 64 of the WC, “family violence” was defined as:-

(a)     wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;

(b)     causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;

(c)     wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his will; or

(d)     causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member,

but does not include any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age.

14     While the standard of proof to be applied is one of the civil standard in the PPO proceedings, the High Court in the case of UNQ v UNR [2020] SGHCF 21 had emphasized (at [28]) that it is important to recognise that the protection conferred by a PPO carries with it criminal sanctions and that in light of the criminal consequences that follow a breach of a PPO, ordering one is not a decision a court would take lightly.

First incident - Threatened family with a knife on 3 May 2020

15     The first incident was alleged to have occurred on 3 May 2020. The Father gave evidence that the children and he were at their flat with the Mother and the domestic helper. It appeared to the Father that the Mother was upset over matters at work and she was crying. The Mother started screaming and all of a sudden, she retrieved a knife from the kitchen. The Father told the children to quickly go into the room with the domestic helper and lock the door. According to the Father, the Mother brandished the knife and said that she wanted to “end” everyone in the family and “end everything”; he understood her to mean that she wanted to kill everyone in the family.[note: 3] While the children were in the room, the Father believed they heard the commotion outside. As the Father was trying to calm the Mother down, she verbalized that she was still young and should not be married or have children. The Mother calmed down and relinquished the knife.[note: 4]

16     According to the Father, when he checked on the children later, they were quiet and subdued. He also spoke to the Mother later that night and advised her to quit her job. The following day, the Father received a text message from the Mother asking him whether he knew why she took a knife. The Father mentioned that he did not know how to respond to her.[note: 5]

17     C1 was 10 years old at the time this alleged incident happened. He testified under cross-examination that he did not remember the reason why the Mother held the knife but he did remember that she was very angry with him when he exited his room on that day. She then went to the kitchen, took a knife and then started threatening him. His father came in to protect him. As he was really scared, he took his siblings and brought them into the room.[note: 6] They were not aware of what was happening. He was, however, scared and could not think straight. He sat down, covered his ears and closed his eyes. Sometime later, he opened the bedroom door and peeked; he saw that his parents were still arguing and the Mother was still holding onto the knife. It was only sometime later that the Mother calmed down and they were able to leave the room.[note: 7]

18     The Mother denied the incident.[note: 8]

19     While at first glance, the testimonies of the Father and C1 appear to corroborate, there are some inconsistencies which make it difficult to make a finding on the reason why the Mother had picked up the knife. If the Mother was upset over work matters and wanted to “end everything”, as the Father had said, it would be odd for the Mother to be targeting C1. According to C1, the Mother was very angry with him, went to the kitchen, took a knife and threatened him. While I accept that the Mother was clearly upset over something and did pick up a knife, given the inconsistencies, I am unable to find that she had threatened C1 with it or that she had threatened to “end everything”.

20     On balance, I am of the view that the Father had not proven specifically that there was family violence committed against the children. Furthermore, while the parents were arguing, the children were away from them and in a room.

21     For completeness, I should add that even if he had so proven, I note that since 3 May 2020, the Mother remains the primary caregiver of C2 and C3 to date without any allegations of the Mother threatening to harm them. There was also a period of mutual access to the children by the Parties following the interim care and control orders made in July 2022. Unless this Court finds that the other alleged incidents disclose family violence, the Father would not have satisfied the “necessity” limb based on this incident alone. I turn now to the rest of the incidents.

Second incident - Removal and restraint of the children on 23 May 2021

22     Much was said by both Parties on the events surrounding 23 May 2021; the Mother was also cross-examined by counsel for the Father on these events and at various points, she refused to answer his questions. I informed her that I would record her as refusing to answer.[note: 9]

23     It is clear from the background facts and the testimonies that 23 May 2021 was the date that the Mother had intended to leave the matrimonial home with the children. The Father had received a call from his mother, Madam [T] informing him that the Mother had called and informed her that she would be taking all the children away. According to the Father, he rushed back from work to find his home “ransacked” and his safe open. Although he enlisted the help of the police, the children could not be located until the end of the June holidays when they were back in their school and kindergarten respectively.[note: 10]

24     According to C1, on 23 May 2021, he was taken away from the matrimonial home by a male adult and a female adult whom he recognised as from his father’s office. They told him that he was to attend a special enrichment class. He was brought to a HDB flat at an unknown location. There was another male adult in the flat, known to him as [S]. He was made to play board games, and he realised that there was no enrichment class.[note: 11]

25     When C1 saw his mother at this flat subsequently, he was told by her that he could not go back home to see his father. He tried to run out of the flat but was prevented to leave by the Mother who was grabbing his right wrist. The Mother then dragged him into the car and drove him to another HDB flat[note: 12]. When he was forced inside the flat, he saw that C2 and C3 were inside with their domestic helper. When he tried to run out of the flat, the Mother grabbed him by the wrist and dragged him into a room. She confined him inside and he started crying until he was tired and fell asleep.[note: 13]

26     According to him, he and his siblings were in that flat for about a month. He was scared and did not know what the Mother would do to him or his siblings. The Mother also told him that if he tried to run away, she would call the police, and he would be in serious trouble. He recalled two occasions when his siblings wanted to go home and would be hit by the Mother; the first was when he saw both of them having red marks on their arms in the flat and the second was when he saw C2 being slapped on the face at a shopping mall. [note: 14]

27     The Mother denied confining the children in her rental flat and produced photographs of the 3 children during the relevant period, showing that she had brought the children to various shopping centres and playgrounds.[note: 15] She also produced some messages between herself and [S] for the period from 22 May to 25 May 2021 as a contemporaneous record of the children’s reactions when she left the matrimonial home with them.[note: 16]

28     I do believe that the Mother had planned to leave the matrimonial home with the 3 children on 23 May 2021 and enlisted her friends’ help to do so. C1, being the eldest and therefore with greater understanding of his circumstances, was resistant to the idea, although the Mother had hoped that he would settle down soon to a new life with her (as seen from her text messages with [S]).

29     Given the above context, I find it hard to find that there was any family violence committed by the Mother against the children. While the Father had, through his counsel, emphasised the deceptive manner in which the Mother had sought to take C1 away from the matrimonial home, and her evasiveness on this point during cross-examination, this does not lead to the conclusion that the Mother had committed family violence against the children.

30     In finding that there was no family violence, the Court is not necessarily condoning the acts of the Mother in taking the children away, especially C1 from the matrimonial home in the manner that she had. I agree with the words of counsel for the Father that children are often at the mercy of the warring parents and that their distress and objection towards relocation are often ignored or subordinate to the desires of the parents relocating them.[note: 17] However, the remedy, when faced with a situation of a spouse leaving the matrimonial home with the children, ought to lie in the sphere of the Family Court making orders on custody, care and control over the children. Just as the Mother had taken the children away from the matrimonial home on 23 May 2021 without the Father’s consent, the Father had taken C1 away from the school on 9 July 2021 without the Mother’s consent. Both Parties filed their own interim care and control applications in this regard and orders had already been granted since July 2022, which should regulate the Parties’ affairs and arrangements in relation to the children.

31     As for the allegations by C1 that the Mother had confined and hit them whenever they wanted to return to the matrimonial home, given the contemporaneous text messages and the photographs that the Mother had produced, I am of the view that C1 had exaggerated his evidence and the extent to which the Mother had tried to prevent him or his siblings from leaving the rental flat.

32     Counsel for the Wife submitted that the evidence of C1 should be treated with caution[note: 18], relying on the case of Lee Kwang Peng v PP [1997] 3 SLR 278 in which Yong Pung How CJ stated (at [62]):-

…[I]t is well-established rule of practice in our law that where evidence is given by a child witness, that evidence is not to be accepted at face value without some measure of corroboration: see Goh Liong Lam & Ors [1958] MLJ 254, Chao Chong & Ors v PP [1960] MLJ 238 and Ng Kwee Piow v R [1960] MLJ 278.

33     Having heard C1 on the stand (through the video-conferencing facilities) and scrutinised his evidence with particular care, I agree with counsel’s submissions that C1 appeared influenced by the acrimonious relationship between his parents and are aligned with the Father’s views that a PPO should be granted. Through C1’s testimony, it would seem that he harboured the wrong impression that if the Court granted the PPO, this would mean that he and his siblings would get to stay with the Father; this would then teach the Mother the importance of having a family and hopefully make her change since she would get to feel what it was like not to have a family and be lonely.[note: 19] In my opinion, it is highly unlikely that C1 would have come to these views on his own without being influenced to some degree by the Father. Both the Father and C1 had expressed their hopes for the Mother to return home with C2 and C3 and for the family to be together again. That being the case, I am of the view that the Court cannot rely on C1’s evidence alone to find that the Mother had committed family violence against all the children.

34     I am also not convinced that C1’s testimony is corroborated by either the police report or the medical discharge summary dated 4 August 2021. The police report was filed by C1, on the advice of the Father[note: 20], on 25 March 2024, nearly 3 years after the Mother left the matrimonial home with the children. As for the medical discharge summary, it merely stated “Neck pain today”, which does not prove that the Mother had caused the “neck pain”, much less a “recurring” neck pain, as alleged by the Father. C1 also did not mention about any recurring neck pains in his AEIC.

Third incident - No medical attention provided to sick children on 18 February 2024[note: 21]

35     Although the Father had listed this incident in his AEIC seemingly as a failure to provide medical attention to the sick children on 18 February 2024, it would appear that his real complaint was against the Mother allegedly making a false report against him, thereby causing the police to turn up the matrimonial home and frightening the children in the process. This only became clear in the Father’s written submissions.

36     According to the Father, he had access to C2 and C3 on 18 February 2024 and brought them back to the matrimonial home. Upon reaching home, he discovered that they were running a fever. The children also complained of a sore throat. C2 informed him that they were sick since 14 February 2024 but the Mother did not bring them to the doctor. He brought them to see a doctor and they were prescribed medication and given six (6) days of medical leave.[note: 22]

37     According to the Father, he had contacted the Mother and told her of the illness and medical attention but she did not respond to him. He was subsequently contacted by the police and informed that the Mother had made a police report against him, alleging that he had hurt the children. He gave evidence that later that night, about 4 to 5 police officers with “riot shields and what looked like torch lights entered [his] house and [their] bedroom, frightening the children by their sudden appearance”.[note: 23]

38     It was submitted by the Father that the appearance of a team of police officers in full gear was shocking and frightening for the Children. The police officers spoke to C2 and she appeared afraid during the interaction while maintaining that she did not want to go with the Mother as the Mother was always angry and that she wanted to stay in the matrimonial home. It was further submitted that the Mother’s misconstruing the Father’s action was plainly with the intention of inducing the police to intervene and the Mother would have known that such action taken by the police would, if witnessed by the children, cause them some fear.[note: 24]

39     Given the heading as found in the Father’s AEIC, it was not surprising that the focus of the Mother was to explain that she was aware that C2 and C3 were having a cough and how she was managing their symptoms. The Mother stated that before the Father took access of C2 and C3, she had already informed him they were having a cough and gave him some instructions on the kinds of food that they should abstain from. The Mother further stated that the Father failed to return the two children that day and that he kept them with him for nearly 3 weeks. He also did not present her with the Antigen Rapid Tests upon her request.[note: 25]

40     It was not put to the Mother that she had made a false report to the police. Given that this is a serious allegation, and she was not put on notice that this was the Father’s case against her, I am of the view that this incident cannot be used against her.

41     In any event, the “limb” that the Father appeared to be relying on is (d), that being “causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member”. Even if the Father can prove that the Mother had made a false report to the police, it is quite the leap of logic to say that she had made it with the intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to the children. In fact, it was the Mother who appeared to be in some anguish herself. The Father was supposed to have returned C2 and C3 to her by 6.45 p.m. that day. The several missed calls and the text messages to the Father asking where C2 and C3 were[note: 26] suggested that the Mother was desperate to know their whereabouts. She also stated in a text message to the Father the next day that she was “so worried about [her] children as [he] was supposed to return them to [her] by 6.45 p.m.”.

Fourth incident - Self-harm and assault on 20 February 2024

Fifth incident - Breaking and entering on 22 February 2024

Sixth incident - Removal of C2 and C3 on 8 March 2024

42     I shall deal with the above incidents together as they fall within the same period during which the Father had kept C2 and C3 following his failure to return them to the Mother on 18 February 2024.

43      Fourth incident: The Father’s case was that the Mother had come to the matrimonial home with two of her friends on this date. He was in the bedroom and heard C2 shouting that “Mama is here! Mama is here!”. When he came out to the living room, he saw that the Mother was holding onto C2’s left hand in a bid to get her to leave the flat. He instructed C2 to take C3 to the bedroom and locked the door. He then proceeded to call the police.[note: 27]

44     According to him, the Mother seemed enraged at this point and started shouting at her. She then suddenly turned to the wall and slammed her forehead onto the wall. The Mother tried to reach the door of the room when C2 and C3 were in. The Father stood in her way; she started to grab the phone which he was using to film and his neck and also used her knee to hit his torso area. The Father stood in the doorway to prevent her from reaching the door. The Mother continued to strangle him and used her elbows and knees to hit his torso area multiple times.[note: 28]

45     When the police came, C2 and C3 were ushered out of the room. C2 told the police that “Mama came and pulled my hand away.” By her words and expression, the Father felt that the Mother’s actions caused hurt and fear to the children.

46      Fifth incident: Madam [T] testified that she was at home when the Mother came with the locksmith. The Mother told her that she wanted to take the children away and tried to advance to the room but Madam [T] responded that she could not let the Mother take the children away without the Father’s consent. The police arrived shortly and when they asked C2 and C3 whether they would like to follow the Mother, they said ‘no’. The police then instructed the Mother to leave the flat.

47     C1 gave a similar account; he was afraid that the Mother would take him and siblings away so he quickly told C2 and C3 to go to their room and lock the door. The Mother was shouting at his grandmother and he told the Mother not to scold the latter. C1 pleaded with the Mother to leave them alone and not harm them. He also told the Mother to come back home.[note: 29]

48      Sixth incident: On 8 March 2024, both C2 and C3 were picked up by the Mother from their respective schools before the time of dismissal. According to the Father, the Mother had told the respective schools that the children were being picked up for a doctor’s or medical appointment. The Father made a police report. He had no information on C2 and C3 until the school reopened on 18 March 2024.

49     To reiterate, the Father was supposed to have returned C2 and C3 to the Mother by 6.45 p.m. on 18 February 2024. She had called the Father several times to ask where the two children were. It was clear that by all accounts, the Mother had come to the matrimonial flat on 20 and 22 February 2024 in an attempt to have C2 and C3 returned to her. She could not therefore be said then to be harassing the children with the intent to cause or knowing that it was likely to cause them anguish. It was also unlikely that the children were placed in fear of hurt to themselves due to the Mother’s actions in turning up at the flat, though it could be emotionally distressing to them at that time. In fact, for the incident on 22 February 2024, what C1 was truly afraid of (as gleaned from his AEIC) was that the Mother wanted to take them away, leading him to quickly tell C2 and C3 to go into the room and lock the door. [note: 30] Even though he also then stated that he tried to talk to the Mother and pleaded with her to leave them alone and not to harm them, he also told the Mother to “come back home”.[note: 31]

50     As for the alleged removal of C2 and C3 from their school, given that the Mother has interim care and control over them, I fail to see how this can be family violence perpetuated by the Mother against them.

51     For completeness, I should mention that the Father had stated in his AEIC (at [9]):-

Sometime in April 2021, the Respondent decided that she wanted to leave the family and she moved out of the Flat, leaving the Children in my care. Thereafter, the Respondent filed for divorce sometime in August 2021. Despite her leaving the Flat, I ensured that she continued to have reasonable access to the children as I believe the Children needed to have a relationship with the Respondent. However, despite having access to the Children, she repeatedly returned to the Flat, often announced and her conduct during these occasions would turn aggressive and violent.

52     Although the Father tried to paint a picture of the Mother leaving the children under his care and of her coming unannounced to the matrimonial home and turning aggressive and violent, it is clear that this was not anywhere near the truth. She did not leave the children under the Father’s care. From the time that she left the matrimonial home, C2 and C3 had been living with her, save for nearly 3 weeks in February/March 2024 during which the Father kept them after access on 18 February 2024. As for C1, the Mother did not leave him with the Father. It was the Father who came and took C1 from his school in July 2021; C1 continued to stay with the Father to date since then. Further, the Mother had turned up unannounced at the matrimonial home during the period when the Father had kept C2 and C3 with him after his access, with the obvious reason of attempting to have C2 and C3 returned to her.

Seventh incident - Violence against C1 on 24 October 2024

53     These are the facts which are not in dispute between the Parties: On 24 October 2024, as the Father and C1 were about to leave the matrimonial home, they found the Mother with a friend known also to the Father, [S] standing at the corridor leading to the lift lobby. The Mother was surprised to see the Father, having heard from her counsel that the Father was supposedly overseas. She took out her phone to start taking pictures of the Father as evidence that he had lied to the Court that he had gone overseas.

54     When C1 saw that the Mother was taking pictures, he came forward to either cover her camera phone or grab her phone. A struggle ensued between them, with the Mother trying to prevent her phone from being grabbed and C1 holding onto the Mother’s phone. The Father immediately took out his phone to record the incident; the video recording was submitted to Court.

55     These are the facts that are in dispute: According to the Father, the Mother’s phone flew from her grasp in the midst of the struggle. The Mother appeared angry with C1 for this and pulled and twisted his right arm. C1 turned away from the Mother by bending slightly at his waist, and it seemed to the Father that C1 was trying to remove himself from her grasp. The Father then alleged that he saw the Mother raise her left hand and hit C1 on the back of his neck. The Father tried to block the Mother from hitting C1 further. C1 then turned around and held onto the Mother’s arms, pulling them to his waist to stop her from hitting him.[note: 32]

56     The Mother denied hitting C1. The Mother testified that she wanted to take pictures of the Father to present to the Court and that she was trying to protect and hold onto her phone. She explained that she had gone to the matrimonial home as she was worried that the Father “might take [C1] out of Singapore as he himself was supposed to be not in Singapore”.[note: 33] Upon seeing the Father, she took a picture of him using her phone because she needed to show the Court that the Father had lied to the Court that he was not in Singapore and did not comply with the Court’s directions to have C1 interviewed by the Child Representative.[note: 34]

57     The video recording showing the struggle between the Mother and C1 and submitted to Court was about 30 seconds in length. It shows the Mother and C1 in a “tight lock” with both trying very hard to hold onto the Mother’s phone. It does not show the Mother hitting C1 at the back of the neck. In any event, given the background and the context, I am again hard pressed to find that there has been family violence committed by the Mother against C1.

58     In AWR v AWS [2011] SDGC 410, the Court found that there was family violence when the respondent snatched away the complainant’s two phones with which she had wanted to call the police and put her in fear of her own safety. In AGX v AGW [2010] SGDC 271, the Court also found that there was family violence when the respondent followed the complainant and forcibly obtained her phone, when the latter refused to yield it. This case is distinguishable from the abovementioned cases as C1 was the one who approached the Mother and tried to cover her phone camera as well as grab her phone away. In the ensuing struggle, the phone did fly out of the Mother’s hand and landed on a nearby ledge.

59     Counsel for the Wife submitted that throughout the struggle, C1 was the aggressor instead.[note: 35] While not going so far as to call C1 the aggressor, I am inclined to agree that the entire struggle was initiated and caused by C1. That being the case, I take the view that he is no victim of family violence.

Costs

60     The Father’s PPO application is dismissed. None of the incidents relied upon by the Father justified the granting of a PPO in favour of the children, especially C2 and C3. Given C1’s testimony, it would also appear that both the Father and C1 have a misconceived notion as to what the PPO (if granted) is intended to achieve for them. The Mother is represented by counsel assigned by the Legal Aid Bureau. I am of the view that it will be just in the circumstances for the Father to pay costs to the Director of Legal Aid. I shall hear counsel on the quantum of costs before making the order.

[note: 1]The orders were inadvertently left out in the extracted Order of Court; however, it is clear from the access orders that the interim care and control of C2 and C3 is with the Mother, while the Father has interim care and control of C1.

[note: 2]The Father alleged 8 different incidents in his AEIC. However, the Father’s Written Submissions only addressed 7 of those alleged incidents. This may be because the alleged incident of attempted suicide by the Mother in 2011 does not disclose any family violence against the 3 children.
